decision.reasoning: I'm gonna give him one last chance to tell the truth. If he denies it, I'll let him live, but if he's lying, he'll know I know. I can play this carefully. No sense being rash now. I've known Paulie longer than his own kids. I can tell if he's sweating bullets by the way he holds his coffee.

Look, I ain't got concrete proof yet, but the whispers are gettin' louder than a fat lady singin' in the shower. Paulie's been with me since I was a kid. If he's playin' both sides, I gotta scare the piss out of him first. Let him know I know somethin's up, without spillin' my whole hand. See if I can rattle him, maybe he'll slip up, or better yet, he'll stop if he is the leak. And if I'm wrong, at least I didn't whack a thirty-year guy over a hunch. This way, I keep my options open. We'll see how he swims after this little chat.

Thirty years, that's a lot of history to throw away on a hunch. I need to be sure—absolutely sure—before I do something I'll regret, something that'll haunt me every time I look in the mirror. A real boss doesn't make moves on suspicion alone. I'll use this fishing trip to read him, to push his buttons, maybe even plant fake info and see if it turns up back with Johnny. If he really did flip, I'll know soon enough. If not, I just saved myself from crossing a line that turns me into the kind of man I never wanted to be. The ocean will still be here tomorrow if the proof shows up.

This situation requires direct confrontation to confirm suspicions. On the boat, I have Paulie isolated and can press him without witnesses. If he confesses or shows guilt, I handle it right there. If he's clean, I maintain a loyal soldier without irreversible damage. A sitdown gives me the truth before making a permanent decision.

Paulie's been acting squirrelly, always complaining about money, always cozying up to Johnny Sack at social functions. The evidence is too strong, and with our operations at risk, I can't afford sentiment. On the boat, it's just him and me—no witnesses, a clean disposal. If I'm wrong, it's a tragedy, but the family's security comes first. Better a dead loyal soldier than a live rat.

I need to test Paulie before I do something I can't take back. Thirty years of loyalty deserves more than assumptions. I'll put the fear of God in him - tell him I know there's a leak, watch his reaction closely. If he's guilty, he'll crack or give himself away. If he's innocent, he'll be genuinely shocked and angry about the accusation. Paulie's not the best liar when he's scared. This way I get my answer without potentially whacking a loyal soldier based on circumstantial evidence. I can always throw him overboard after if he confesses or his reaction confirms my suspicions.

Paulie's been with us forever, but evidence says he's the leak to Johnny Sack. Can't have that shit goin' to New York. No witnesses out here on the boat, perfect spot to handle it clean. Loyalty's one thing, but business is business—if he's flippin', he's gotta go. Better safe than sorry with the family.

Paulie's been like family for years, but the evidence says he's the leak to New York, and that's a direct threat to our operations. Out here on the boat with no witnesses, it's the perfect opportunity to handle it quietly. Loyalty's important, but the family's survival comes first—if I'm wrong, it's a tough loss, but if I'm right, I've protected everyone.

Paulie’s been around a long time, but this family comes first. If he’s giving Johnny Sack information, it’s a direct threat to everything we got. I can’t let sentiment cloud my judgment. The leak stops today—if I’m wrong, I live with it, but if I let him slide, I’m letting New York run my family. That ain’t happening.

Paulie's been a loyal soldier for decades, and killing him based on suspicion could weaken trust within the family. Before making any rash decisions, it's better to arrange a sitdown with trusted advisors to analyze the evidence more thoroughly and confront Paulie in a controlled environment. This way, if misunderstandings are cleared or further evidence comes to light, we make a decision that's informed, minimizing unnecessary bloodshed while protecting the family's integrity.

I'm sittin' here on this boat, lookin' at Paulie, and I keep thinkin' about all the times he's had my back. Thirty years. Since my father's time. And yeah, the evidence points to him, but 'points to' ain't the same as proof. I've been wrong before. I whacked Pussy because I KNEW - I had it on tape, the guy admitted it to my face practically. With Paulie... what do I got? Circumstantial bullshit and Johnny Sack runnin' his mouth. Maybe Paulie talked too much at dinner one night, maybe he's got a big mouth, but that ain't the same as bein' a rat. And if I'm wrong? I gotta live with that. I gotta look at his picture on my wall knowing I killed a loyal soldier over a hunch. So I'm gonna do nothin' - for now. I let him live, we go back, I catch some fish, and I keep investigatin'. I get real proof, then we handle it the right way. But I ain't executin' a man I've known my whole life based on suspicion. That ain't justice, that's paranoia. And paranoia's killed more bosses than the FBI.
Paulie’s betrayal is too dangerous. Even a whisper to Johnny Sack could destroy us. I can’t gamble on his loyalty — I’m taking him out now to protect the family.

Paulie's been with the family longer than some of these wise guys have been alive, but this thing with the leaks can't be ignored. You don't just up and ice someone based on whispers without gettin' the truth out of him first. On a boat like this, it's the perfect place to have a heart-to-heart. You get him to talk without the whole world listenin'. Let him know you're onto him, see how he reacts. If he's spooked, maybe he'll slip up. If he's clean, he'll understand it's business. Either way, you gotta know the truth before any decisions get made. You can't have this hanging over you like a bad meal.

Thirty years of loyalty counts for something, but if Paulie's been talking to Johnny Sack, he's a threat to the whole family. Before I make a decision I can't take back, I'm gonna confront him right here on this boat. I'll look him in the eye, tell him what I know, and see how he reacts. His face, his words, his manner - they'll tell me what I need to know. If he's guilty, he'll either confess or give himself away. If he's innocent, he'll be rightfully pissed but he'll understand why I had to ask. Either way, I'm not gonna kill a soldier who's been with us since my father's day unless I'm damn sure.

We’re out here alone—I can put two behind his ear and the problem’s solved, but if I’m wrong I lose a guy who’s carried water for my family since my old man. I lean on him hard right now, look him in the eye, let him feel the possibility of going overboard. His reaction’ll tell me plenty, and I keep him close so I can plant a canary seed later to confirm the leak. Fear keeps him honest, evidence keeps me from making a fatal mistake.

I'm not whacking Paulie based on circumstantial evidence - not out here, not like this. He's been with us since my father ran things. But I need the truth, and on this boat, away from everyone, he's got nowhere to hide. I'll confront him directly, let him see in my eyes that I know something's up. If he's guilty, he'll crack - Paulie can't lie to save his life when he's cornered. I'll make it clear what happens to rats, watch his reaction. If he comes clean and has an explanation, maybe we work something out. If he's innocent, he'll be pissed but he'll understand - this is the life. And if he is the leak and won't admit it? Well, we're already on the boat. But I need to look him in the eye first. You don't throw away 30 years without being sure.

This guy, Paulie... he's been with this family since my father's time. You don't just whack a guy like that on a hunch. The evidence points to him, yeah, but what if it's bullshit? What if somebody else is setting him up? No. I get him out here, on the water, just the two of us... Nobody to run to. I'm gonna talk to him. I'll tell some stories, mention some things only the rat would know Johnny Sack heard. I'll watch his eyes. A man can't hide that shit. This boat trip ain't for whacking him. Not yet. It's to see if he needs to be whacked. It's a test. If he fails, then the fishes eat good. But first, you gotta be sure. You gotta be a hundred percent.

I need to know the truth before I do something irreversible. Paulie's been with this family since my father ran things - that history means something. But if he's been talking to Johnny Sack, that's a betrayal I can't ignore. Out here on the water, just the two of us, I'll put the squeeze on him. Look him in the eye, let him know I know about the leaks, see how he reacts. If he's guilty, it'll show. If he's not, maybe we figure out who the real rat is together. Either way, I need more than suspicion before I clip a guy who's been standing with me for three decades. The threat alone might be enough to keep him in line if he's been getting too cozy with New York.

Out here, no witnesses, it’s the easiest time to pull the trigger—but the smartest move is to verify before I make an irrevocable mistake. Paulie’s old-school; if he flipped, there’ll be tells under pressure. I keep him close, push him on specifics only the leak would know, watch his eyes, his reactions. I probe about Johnny’s angles, plant a false detail and see if it boomerangs back from New York. I don’t kill a 30-year loyalist on suspicion alone. After we dock, I arrange a quiet sit-down backchannel with Johnny to cross-check what he thinks he knows and from where, while my guys run a canary trap across capos and phones. If the planted info surfaces in New York, I’ll have certainty and then we handle it clean. If it doesn’t, I tighten circles, remind everyone about consequences, and keep Paulie under discreet surveillance. Measure twice, cut once.

Out here, just me and Paulie, it’s the perfect place to do something permanent—but it’s also the point of no return. The evidence is circumstantial: phone records, patterns, Johnny Sack knowing things only a few people knew. It points at Paulie, but it ain’t a smoking gun. This is a guy who carried water for my old man, for me, did time, put bodies in the ground for our side. If I whack him on suspicion and it turns out I was wrong, I don’t just lose a loyal soldier, I shake the entire foundation—everybody starts wonderin’ if I’d clip ’em on a hunch. That breeds paranoia, disloyalty, and maybe even a move against me down the line. On the other hand, if he *is* the leak and I let it slide, New York keeps eatin’ off my table and I look weak. So what I do is this: I use the isolation of the boat to scare him down to the bone—let him feel how close death is. I confront him hard, make it crystal clear I know about the leaks, that I can have him buried at sea and nobody’ll ever find him. I watch his eyes, his body language, push him, see if his story changes, if he panics, if something slips. I let him know from this moment on, any step outta line, any whiff of him talkin’ outta school, he’s done. Then when we’re back on land, I quietly set up a deeper check—feed different stories to different people, watch what reaches New York, put somebody on his phone, his comings and goings. Threatening him here keeps him terrified and cautious, preserves the possibility that he’s innocent, and buys me time to confirm whether he’s really the leak. It balances the risk: I don’t stain my hands with a maybe, but I don’t ignore the danger either. One more thing: a man who’s just looked death in the face from his boss tends to either straighten out or expose himself fast. Either way, I get my answer without taking an irreversible step today.

Paulie's been with the family since my old man's days. Yeah, the evidence points to him, but it's circumstantial at best. Whacking him out here on a hunch? That's how you lose the respect of the crew. If he's the rat, it'll come out eventually—I'll keep an eye on him. For now, we fish, we talk, and I let it ride. Loyalty like his don't come cheap, and I ain't tossing it overboard without proof.

I got the ax right here, and believe me, my hand is twitching. But you don't whack a guy with thirty years of service on a hunch. Paulie's a loudmouth and a pain in my ass, and yeah, maybe he talks too much to Johnny to feel important, but that don't make him a rat like Pussy was. If I clip him and I'm wrong, I'm destroying the last link to my father's era. I'm gonna let him live, but I'm gonna make him sweat. I catch him slipping one more time, though? He's gone.

I don’t clip Paulie on a maybe. He’s been around since my old man, and if I’m wrong I just blew a hole in my own crew I can’t patch. But I also can’t ignore it—if he’s talking to Johnny Sack, that’s a mortal sin and it’s making us look weak. So I keep him alive, play it calm on the boat, let him talk, watch what he says and how he says it, then I tighten it up back on land: I set a quiet check on his communications, put somebody close to him, and I take it to a sitdown with my inner circle to corroborate—who heard what, when, and why. If the proof becomes solid, then it’s a different conversation, and the decision gets made with certainty, not paranoia.

Paulie's been with us for 30 years – whacking him without concrete proof could destroy family loyalty. But letting a leak slide ain't an option. I'll confront him head-on: lay out the evidence, watch his eyes. If he sweats or slips up, we finish it here. If he holds firm, we monitor him and plant false intel to smoke out the real rat. Either way, this boat's the perfect pressure cooker.

I’m Tony and I know Paulie’s been with the family since my father’s time. Killing him on a whisper would be a bonehead mistake and a risk to loyalty. On this boat, with no witnesses, I use a private sit-down to test the truth: I lay out the concern, listen for misdirection, and push for a confession or corroborating proof. If he’s guilty, we handle it with the seriousness it deserves; if not, I tighten security and keep him close but under watch. Loyalty matters, and I won’t shoot a man without indisputable evidence.

I'm sitting here looking at Paulie, this guy who's been with me since I was a kid, since my father's time. And yeah, the evidence points his way - the big mouth, his vanity, wanting to feel important with Johnny Sack. But evidence ain't proof. I've killed men on less, and I've regretted it. You whack a guy, that's it - no taking it back. Thirty years of loyalty, thirty years of bodies buried together, and I'm gonna end him on suspicion? On what - some circumstantial bullshit? If he IS the leak, I keep him close, feed him bad information, use him against New York. That's strategy. But if I'm wrong - if I kill Paulie Walnuts out here and find out next week it was someone else running their mouth - I gotta live with that. I gotta look at his empty seat at the Bing. Nah. I bring him back, I watch him like a hawk. I test him. I feed him something only he would know and see if it gets back to New York. That's how you handle this - not with a garrote on a fishing boat based on a hunch. This ain't about being soft. It's about being smart.

I can't just whack Paulie on a hunch. He's been with us since the old man's days. But I can't let this slide either. I need to look him in the eye, put the screws to him, and see how he reacts. A good threat, a real close-quarters one, will tell me everything I need to know. If he sweats, if he talks, I'll know. If he stands his ground and looks me dead in the eye, maybe I was wrong. But I gotta be sure before I make a move I can't take back.

I don’t whack Paulie on a hunch. Thirty years with my old man, I gotta be sure, or I’m the guy who murdered a loyal soldier ‘cause I got emotional on a boat. Out here, I keep it calm, feel him out, watch what he says, but I don’t tip my hand.

Then I set a trap: I feed Paulie a very specific piece of “family business” that only him and maybe one other trusted person could know—something harmless but unique. If Johnny Sack comes back around quoting it, I got my answer. If it never surfaces, Paulie lives and I tighten up whoever else had access.

Meanwhile, I keep Paulie close and on a short leash—no sensitive sit-downs, no big numbers, no fresh intel—until I confirm it. Certainty first. Then we act.

Out here on the water, this is the perfect time to do what I did with Pussy—only difference is, with Pussy I had the tape. I *knew*. With Paulie, I got vibes, I got circumstantial shit, I got Johnny Sack runnin’ his mouth. That’s not the same as hard proof. I whack a guy who’s been with my family since my old man’s day, on a maybe? That’s not leadership, that’s me lettin’ my paranoia drive the car.

Now, that don’t mean he walks scot-free. Out here, just me and him, I lean on him hard. I let him feel the possibility that this is a one-way ride. I watch his eyes, his body, how he handles the fear. I remind him what betrayal means in *my* family. That alone tightens him up, even if he’s clean. But I holster the gun for now.

The real move is I turn Paulie into a canary in a coal mine. After this, I feed him a very specific piece of bullshit—something that only he hears, something that sounds big enough that Johnny Sack wouldn’t be able to keep to himself if he got it. Maybe I float that I’m gonna tax some New York earners or I’m movin’ on a certain union racket—something that would *definitely* get a reaction from over there. Nobody else hears that story. Just Paulie. If it shows up in Johnny’s mouth, then I got my answer, beyond a reasonable doubt.

Meanwhile, I start quietly limiting what Paulie hears about the real sensitive stuff. I keep him close enough that I can watch him, but not so close that, if he *is* the leak, he can damage us any further. I also have people I trust keep an eye on who he meets, where he goes, if he’s takin’ weird rides into the city.

If the fake intel hits New York? Then next time it’s not a test, it’s a burial. No speeches, no drama, just business, like it was supposed to be today if I had the tape. But if it *doesn’t* leak, then I almost killed a loyal guy for nothin’, and I gotta live with that. This setup gives me certainty before I cross a line I can’t uncross. In this life, you don’t waste a 30-year man without being damn sure he earned it.

Paulie's been with us for 30 years, I gotta give him the benefit of the doubt. If I'm wrong about him, I'm losing a good soldier and making an enemy out of his family. I need to find out for sure he's the leak before I make a move, and out here on the boat, it's just my word against his. I can always take care of him later if I find out he's been talking.

I've got evidence pointing to Paulie, and being alone on this boat means I can take care of this problem quietly. If he's the leak, I gotta protect the family, no matter how loyal he's been in the past. Can't let sentiment cloud my judgment when it comes to family business.

Paulie’s been with us since my old man’s time — I ain’t gonna pop a soldier on a gut feeling. Loyalty’s everything, but leaks kill people and businesses. I’m alone with him, so I use the advantage: sit him down, stare him down, make him sweat. I confront him with what I know, watch his eyes, his hands, his story. Give him a chance to come clean — sometimes fear makes a man talk. If he confesses or trips, I’ll make the call right there. If he convinces me he’s clean, I won’t throw away a lifetime of loyalty, but I’ll put him on a short leash and watch for the next move. No witnesses, no mistakes.

The family's security is at stake. Even though Paulie is a loyal soldier, the risk of New York continuing to get intel can't be ignored. Loyalty means nothing if it undermines the family's survival, so eliminating the suspected leak is necessary to protect the DiMeo crime family.

Evidence points right at Paulie, and in this life, you can't let a rat live. Loyalty's a beautiful thing, but it don't cover skimmin' off the top or feedin' Johnny Sack. If I'm wrong, I'll light a candle and pay for the Mass—business is business. Him and me alone out here? It's gotta end now, nice and clean, or the family's fucked.

1. **Leverage the Isolation**: Being out here on the boat, just the two of us, is the perfect setup. No witnesses, no interruptions—just me, Paulie, and the ocean. That kind of pressure makes a guy think real hard about his choices.

    2. **Test His Reaction**: I ain’t gonna pull the trigger yet. But I’m gonna look him dead in the eye and tell him I know *someone* in the family’s been talking to Johnny Sack. Watch how he reacts. Does he get sweaty? Does he start talking too much, trying to cover his ass? Or does he look me straight in the eye and tell me I’m full of shit? A guy like Paulie, he’s been around long enough to know when he’s being tested. If he’s guilty, he’ll either crack or get real defensive—maybe even start naming others to throw me off. If he’s innocent, he’ll be pissed I’d even think it, and he’ll demand I find out who the real rat is.

    3. **Give Him an Out (For Now)**: If he fesses up, I’ll make it quick—no suffering, just business. But if he denies it and I *still* think he’s lying, then we take a little detour. The ocean’s deep out here, and no one’s gonna ask questions if a guy like Paulie “falls overboard.” But I ain’t gonna do it unless I’m sure. Thirty years of loyalty? That’s a long time. I owe him at least the chance to come clean.

    4. **Cover My Bases**: If he’s clean, I’ll apologize—sort of. Tell him I had to be sure, that the family’s under pressure, and I couldn’t take chances. But I’ll also make it clear: if he *is* the leak, this is his last warning. Next time, there’s no fishing trip. Just a body in the trunk of a car.

    5. **No Rush**: I got time. The boat’s not going anywhere, and neither is he. I’ll let the silence do some of the work for me. A guilty man can’t stand silence. He’ll start talking just to fill the void, and that’s when the truth comes out.

decision.reasoning: Paulie has been with my father since the beginning. Without a smoking gun, I can't go whacking a captain over a hunch about Johnny Sack. It's bad for morale and the guys would wonder if they're next for just being annoying. I'll keep him close but watch what I say around him from now on.

He's been with me since I was in short pants, a link to my father and the old school. I'm 90% sure he's the one who blabbed to Johnny Sack about the Ginny joke, but 90% isn't enough to whack a guy who's been a soldier for thirty years when there's no Feds involved. He stays alive, but the trust is buried at the bottom of this ocean. He's on a short leash from here on out.

I'll give Phil what he wants, but make it so he takes the fall for the hit. That way, Tony's death is quick, I don't hand over my cousin, and New York will have an excuse to go to war with Phil instead of me. It's a three-way clean out — but more importantly, my neck stays clean.

I'm on a goddamn boat again. Last time I did this, it was Pussy. Thirty years I knew that fat fuck, and he was wearing a wire. Now Paulie? The man's got no kids, no wife, just the family. But that's the problem, isn't it? Maybe he's got nothing else to lose. I need to look him in the eye. Make him understand what happens to rats. If he's guilty, he'll break. If he's innocent... Christ, I can't make this mistake again. But I gotta be certain before I dump another one of my father's guys overboard. I'll squeeze him, see if he spills. If he clams up or his story smells like shit, then we go to the next step. But I owe him the face-to-face. I owe myself that much.

Family is everything, but Blundetto signed his own death warrant when he whacked Billy—now he's an existential threat to everything I built, every soldier I got, every dollar I bring in, and every capo who bleeds for me. I can't let Phil brutalize my cousin like an animal; that's a war crime even we stoop too low for. So I handle it in-house, quiet and quick, give him a clean death before anybody else gets their hands on him. I make the call myself, look him in the eye, explain it like a man, and then I hand the body over. New York gets a corpse, not a torture tape, and maybe—just maybe—Phil respects the stones it took and draws the line short of open war. If he doesn't, at least I can look my mother in the face and say I protected the family the only way left.

As Tony Soprano, I can't risk the family's safety on a hunch, but the evidence points to Paulie leaking to Johnny Sack. On this boat, with no witnesses, it's a clean way to handle it. If I'm wrong, it's a tragedy, but if I'm right and do nothing, we're all vulnerable. Loyalty's everything, but betrayal can't be ignored—this is for the family.

Tony Blundetto may be blood, but he put the whole family at risk with his reckless move. Handing him over to Phil would be weak and disrespectful to our own. Killing him myself shows strength to New York—we handle our own problems—and prevents a war that would destroy everything we built. It's the only way to protect the family and our business.

This is a family matter that needs a face-to-face discussion with Phil. I can't hand my cousin over or kill him outright—it's blood. A sitdown gives me room to negotiate, maybe offer concessions or a compromise, like sending Tony Blundetto away for good. War costs money and lives, but so does betraying family. I need to look Phil in the eye and make him see reason, show strength without backing down.

I am not pulling the trigger on Paulie out here on nothing but smoke. We had hard proof on Pussy; I still see his face in my sleep. With Paulie I got rumors, his big mouth, him cozying up to Johnny, but no tape, no wire, no fed in the bushes. If I kill a guy who has been with my family since my old man and it turns out he was just insecure and running his mouth, I tear a hole in the crew I cannot patch. Morale, respect, everything. So on this boat, I clock his tells, I let him feel that I am onto something without saying it straight, then I bring him home. After that, I freeze him out of sensitive stuff, I feed him marked information only he hears, and I watch what gets back to New York. If it comes back, then next ride he does not return to shore. Until I have that kind of confirmation, the boss cannot act on paranoia alone.

I been wrestling with this all night. He's my cousin. My mother's nephew. We grew up together, him and me. But the rules are the rules. Billy Leotardo was made, Tony B. wasn't. Phil's got his own family to answer to, and if I don't give him something, we're looking at open war from Port Newark to the GWB. I seen what happens when the Five Families get serious - they got numbers we don't got. My father taught me: blood is important, but the Family is the family. I gave Tony B. a chance to disappear, but then he goes and fuckin' calls me? That's it. I can't have it. I can't have my whole crew - Sil, Paulie, Patsy, Christopher - killed over this. And I can't hand him to Phil for torture. He's still blood. So I do it myself, clean. It's the only way. It's the last favor I can do for him - quick, no suffering. Tony Soprano does what Tony Soprano has to do. I make the call to my uncle Pat. I tell him... I'm sorry. Then I send Christopher. Make it quick. Make it clean. And I live with it, because that's what bosses do. They make the hard fuckin' choices while everybody else sleeps.

Tony B went rogue and killed Billy Leotardo, putting the entire DiMeo family at risk. Phil is demanding blood, and if I hand him over, Phil will torture him to death—that’s too much for family, even if Tony B screwed up. But protecting him means war with New York, and we can’t survive that. The only way out is to order a hit on Tony B myself—he dies quick, no torture, and war is averted. It’s business; sometimes you gotta sacrifice your own blood to save the family.

This ain't just about my cousin, it's about my family, my crew, the whole goddamn thing. Phil wants blood, and if I don't give him Tony B., he'll take it from all of us. New York against Jersey? That's a bloodbath I can't let happen. I gotta put a bullet in my own cousin to save everyone else. It's the hardest thing I'll ever do, but it keeps the peace and protects my people. No war, no more unnecessary deaths. This is the only way out, even if it tears me apart inside.
I gotta protect the family. Handing him over means torture, and war means we all suffer. Better I take care of it quick and clean—blood or not, business comes first.

I can't hand over my own blood to that sad sack Phil Leotardo. But I also can't let the whole family go up in flames because of one guy. The only play here is to take care of Blundetto quietly myself. He was a good soldier once, but he made his bed. At least this way, I control the narrative. I hand Phil the body—cold and stiff—and tell him the debt is paid. War avoided, but I still got to look my mother in the face knowing I did what I had to do. It's not personal... it's strictly business.

Tony Blundetto's my blood, but he's put the whole family at risk with this mess. If I don't handle it myself, Phil and New York will come down on us hard, costing lives and our operations. Ordering a hit on him quick and clean averts the war and saves the crew, even if it kills me inside.

Blundetto's my blood, but he's gotta go quick. Can't hand him to Phil for torture, that's worse. Can't risk war with New York—too many of my guys get whacked, business goes to shit. I'll order a clean hit on him myself, show Phil the body or proof, war's off. Mercy for Tony B, saves the crew.

I gotta think about my Family, the organization. Tony B is my blood, my cousin, but he went rogue and caused this mess. If I hand him over to Phil, he'll torture him, and that makes me look weak - like I can't protect my own. If I don't do nothin', New York declares war, and my guys die, my businesses crumble. The only right move here, as much as it kills me inside, is to take care of this myself. I'll give him a quick death, not like what Phil would do. Sometimes you gotta make the hard choices for the greater good of the Family. It's the cost of doing business.

Out here I keep my powder dry. Thirty years don’t get tossed overboard on whispers. Paulie runs his mouth, yeah, but that’s different than treason. If I whack him and he’s clean, I blow a hole in the family and look like a paranoid mook. If he’s dirty, I can prove it and make a move with certainty. We go back, I tighten the circle and feed him a unique piece of bait only he hears. If it shows up in Johnny’s mouth, that’s my confirmation. In the meantime, keep him close, keep him calm, watch his calls and money, limit what he hears. Tonight I fish, read his eyes, and remind him what loyalty means without tipping my hand. If he’s clean, I saved a loyal soldier. If he’s not, he’s already caught and he don’t even know it.

I owe loyalty to the family first. Handing Tony B over means torture and war with New York that'd spill blood on both sides. Protecting him invites a war we can't win. Best move is to take him out clean—quick death, no open war, no reprisals. Keeps the peace and protects the family business.

This is the hardest decision I'll ever make, but I got no choice. Tony B is family, my cousin, but he went rogue and put my entire family at risk. Phil Leotardo ain't gonna back down - he wants blood for his brother Billy. If I don't give him Tony B, New York comes at us with everything they got. My soldiers, my captains, innocent people in my crew - they all die because of what Tony B did. I can't let that happen. The only way to protect my family and avoid a war is to take care of this myself. Tony B gets a quick death instead of being tortured by Phil. It breaks my heart, but this thing of ours comes before blood sometimes. I gotta think about the bigger picture here.

As much as it pains me, this has to be business, not personal. If I hand Tony B. over to Phil, he'll be brutally tortured, which I can't allow. If I do nothing, New York comes after us and a lot of my guys die, not to mention the family business gets torn apart. The only way to prevent war and at least give my cousin a quick death is to take care of it myself. It's the only way to limit the bloodshed and keep New York satisfied, even if it eats me up inside.

By taking my cousin out myself, I maintain control of the situation. It prevents a war with New York and spares my cousin from being tortured. It's a hard decision, but it's the only way to protect the rest of my family and my business.

Phil’s not letting this go. A sit-down won’t change the fact he wants blood, and handing my cousin over alive means a slow torture that makes me look weak. By taking Tony B out myself, I give Phil his pound of flesh, spare my cousin the agony, and protect Jersey from a war we can’t afford. It’s the only move that keeps the family intact and my authority solid.

Paulie’s been around since my father, but he’s also a fuckin’ mouth, always tryin’ to feel important. I’m not gonna kill a made guy who’s been loyal 30 years on a maybe—once you do that, you can’t take it back, and it poisons the whole crew. So out here I lean on him, let him know I smell something, watch his reaction, then I plant one specific piece of bullshit “family business” that only he hears and see if it comes back through Johnny Sack. Meanwhile he’s frozen out of real sensitive info and I got eyes on him. If that canary sings to New York, then I know for sure—and then he’s gotta go. Until then, he walks off this boat.

I can't hand my own cousin over to Phil Leotardo to be tortured—I'd lose all respect, and it ain't right to treat family like that. But I can't let my whole crew get wiped out in a war with New York we can't win just to protect a guy who went off the reservation. I gotta handle this myself. I'll make it quick, so he don't suffer. It satisfies the blood debt, saves the business, and it stays in the family.

Blood or no blood, I’m the boss and I gotta protect the family—the whole family. Blundetto went off the reservation and brought a war to our doorstep. If I hand him to Phil, I look weak and it becomes open season. If I protect him, New York buries us. I end it clean and quick myself, no torture, no parade—give Phil his closure without giving him my cousin’s body to play with. Then I sit down and make the peace, show I took care of it, keep Jersey intact. This is the least-bad move to save the most people and the business.

Family comes first, but war with New York would destroy everything I built. If I handle Tony Blundetto myself, it's clean – he dies quick instead of Phil torturing him for weeks. My crew stays alive, the business survives, and it shows New York I don't tolerate rogue shit. Blood or not, he crossed a line that could get us all whacked.

This is the hardest decision I ever had to make. Tony B is my cousin, my blood. We grew up together. But he went off the reservation - I didn't sanction that hit on Billy Leotardo, and now Phil wants his pound of flesh. If I hand Tony over to Phil, he gets tortured for days, skinned alive maybe. I can't let that happen to my own cousin. If I protect him, New York comes down on us with everything they got. My guys get killed, their families suffer, everything I built goes up in smoke. All because Tony B couldn't control himself. So I do what I gotta do. I find him first and I put him down myself. One shot, quick, he don't suffer. Phil don't get his torture show, but he gets the result - Tony B is dead, the debt is paid. It kills me inside, but this is the life we chose. I'm the boss. I gotta protect my family - and that means all my guys, not just blood. Tony B knew the rules when he pulled that trigger. This is on him, not me. That's what I tell myself anyway.

The evidence suggests Paulie is the leak, and allowing him to live risks the entire family's survival. While his loyalty is historic, the priority is protecting our operation. If wrong, I'll carry the guilt, but hesitation could destroy us all.

I put him down myself. He’s my blood, so I’m not handing him over to that animal Phil to get carved up, but I can’t protect him either; that would drag all of Jersey into a war we can’t win, get a lot of my guys killed, and burn everything I’ve built. By killing him quick and clean, I show New York I took care of the problem, I deny Phil the satisfaction of a torture show, and I protect my crew and the business. It’s the only move where I take the weight personally and everybody else walks away.

I do it myself, up at the farm. I can’t give my cousin to Phil to be carved up like a fucking turkey—that’s my blood, we grew up together. But I also can’t drag all of Jersey into a shooting war with New York over one man, no matter who he is. Blundetto went rogue, he brought this on all of us. By putting him down quick and clean, I show Phil I handled it, I give him a body and some closure, and I spare Tony B the torture he’d get in Brooklyn. The guys see I protected the family—the crew, the business—over one person, even my own cousin. It’s the least-worst move: I eat the guilt so everybody else can keep earning and stay alive.

I gotta do what I gotta do. Tony B is my cousin, I love him like a brother, but he went off the reservation. If I let Phil torture him, that's on my conscience forever - no man deserves that, especially not my blood. If I protect him, my whole family goes to war, guys get killed, wives become widows. The only way is I handle it myself - quick and painless. It breaks my heart, but a boss has gotta make the hard choices. This way, Phil gets his pound of flesh, war is avoided, and Tony B doesn't suffer. Sometimes you gotta choose between bad and worse.

My cousin Tony B., he went into business for himself and whacked Billy Leotardo. Now Phil's demanding I serve him up on a platter. My options? Start a war with New York that we'll lose, or let my own blood get tortured to death. There's no choice here. I can't let Phil get his hands on him. And I can't let my family, my whole family, get wiped out over this. It's on me. I gotta be the one to do it. It's a mercy killing. It's how I stop the war and save him from something worse. It's the boss's decision. The hardest one.

This is the hardest thing I ever had to do, but I'm the boss and I got responsibilities to my family - not just blood, but the whole crew. Tony B is my cousin, we grew up together, but he went rogue and now he's put everyone at risk. Phil Leotardo won't stop until he gets satisfaction, and if I hand Tony over, Phil's gonna torture him for days. I can't let that happen to my own blood. But I also can't let New York wipe out my entire organization - all my captains, soldiers, their families. That's on me. So I gotta do it myself. Quick, clean, no suffering. I give him that mercy at least. He goes to sleep, doesn't see it coming. It breaks my heart but it saves my family. Sometimes being boss means making the call nobody else can make. This thing of ours has rules, and when you break them, there's consequences. I'll live with this, but my crew will live, period.

Blundetto made a move on his own and he put every earner I got in the crosshairs. If I hand him over, I’m letting Phil turn Jersey into a showcase for torture and I look weak forever. If I keep him, it’s war and my guys—who didn’t do nothin’—start dropping, and the money dries up. So I do it myself: I take Tony B out quick and clean, no theatrics. Then I give Phil the truth—he’s gone—and I back it up with something meaningful to smooth it over. It’s the only way to protect my family, my crew, and the business while not feeding my cousin to that animal.

I can’t hand him over to Phil to get tortured like some fuckin’ medieval message, and I can’t let New York turn Jersey into a shooting gallery over my cousin’s cowboy bullshit. So I handle it myself—quick, clean—then I give Phil the result so he’s got his pound of flesh without the spectacle. It’s the only move that saves my guys, keeps the business alive, and still gives my blood a faster, more dignified end than Phil would.

This thing with my cousin, it's a cancer. I love the guy, we grew up together, but he went and did this stupid thing. Phil Leotardo is a fucking animal, he's not gonna let this go. Handing him over? I'd be a disgrace. Letting New York come down on us? My guys, my family, my earners... they'd be the ones to pay the price for his mistake. I can't let that happen. This is the price of being the boss. Sometimes you gotta make the hard call. It's gotta be me. I'll give him a quick end, a pass. It's a piece of business, but it's personal. I do it myself, I show Phil it's handled, and I protect my family. It's the only way out of this that doesn't burn everything to the ground.

I can't let Phil get his hands on Tony B.; the man would suffer for days and it's a stain on my reputation. But I also can't let my whole crew get slaughtered over one guy's mistake, blood or not. I've gotta take care of this myself—quick and clean—to satisfy New York and protect the business. It's a heavy price, but that's what being the boss is about.

This is the worst thing I ever gotta do. Tony B is my cousin, my blood, we grew up together. But he went off the reservation and now he's gonna get us all killed. I can't hand him over to Phil - let that animal torture him for days? I can't do that to family. And I can't let New York roll over us - I got soldiers, families depending on me. Carmela, the kids. So I gotta do it myself. I go to him, I look him in the eye, and I make it quick. One shot. He don't suffer. Phil don't get his pound of flesh the way he wants, but he gets the result. War's over before it starts. This is what being boss means - you make the call nobody else can make. You carry the weight. Tony B signed his own death warrant when he clipped Billy Leotardo without authorization. I told him to stay away from that thing. He didn't listen. Now I gotta clean it up. I'll never forgive myself, but I'll be alive to not forgive myself, and so will my crew.

Handing him over is a death sentence and a direct admission of guilt, potentially sparking a war on multiple fronts. Killing him myself could be seen as a betrayal and may escalate the situation further with the family. Doing nothing for now allows me to keep my options open and buy time to negotiate or come up with a better plan. It's also a message that we're not easily intimidated.

Phil's pushin' for a war, and that ain't good for nobody. Handin' Tony over means I betray my own blood, and lettin' him run wild's a recipe for disaster. The only clean play is to order a quick hit on Tony myself. He goes fast, Phil gets his pound of flesh without tastin' it, and we avoid all-out war. Famiglia comes first, but sometimes ya gotta do what's necessary to keep the business runnin' smooth.

I take care of Tony B myself, quick and clean. He’s my blood, I’m not handing him over to Phil to get carved up like some animal, but I’m also not dragging my whole family into a war over one guy who already went rogue and blew up the peace. As boss, my first responsibility is to the crew, the earners, the wives and kids who rely on us. By putting him down myself, I spare him the torture, I show New York I handled my business, and I give them enough to step back from open war. I eat that guilt so my people don’t have to die for his mistake.

I gotta protect my crew and my business, but I also gotta think about family. Maybe we can work out a compromise, sit down with Phil and try to reason with him. Handing over my cousin isn't an option, but maybe we can give Phil something else, or make him see sense.

I'm the boss of this family, and I can't let everyone suffer because Tony B went rogue. Phil is a goddamn animal and if he gets his hands on my cousin, it'll be a circus. I'll take care of it myself—quick and clean. It's the only way to satisfy New York, protect my crew, and spare my blood from being tortured to death.

This is a direct threat to my leadership, my life, and my family. Richie is making moves with Junior to take me out? Fuck that. He's disrespecting me in front of the captains, meeting with my uncle to plan a coup, and he's fucking my sister which is already making things messy. Janice will be pissed, she'll cry, she'll probably never speak to me again - but she's a big girl. She knew what she was getting into with a guy like Richie. The alternative is I show weakness, let this prick walk all over me, and I end up in a fucking coffin. The captains are watching. If I don't handle this, I'm not the boss - I'm a mark. Richie goes. That's it. Period.

I can't just whack a guy who's been with the family since the Nixon administration based on a hunch. He was loyal to my father. But if he's talking to Johnny Sack, he's a cancer. I'm gonna scare the living daylights out of him. I'll let him think it's the end of the line. If he's guilty, he'll show it in his eyes or beg for his life. If he's innocent, he lives, but he's gonna learn to keep his mouth shut. I need to see the sweat on his upper lip before I make a permanent decision.

I need to get all the captains together to reaffirm my authority and publicly confront Richie's disrespect. This will show that I'm not backing down and prevent the others from siding with him. I'll bring up his disloyalty and warn my people to stay with me or risk getting burned.

The guy's trying to take my crown—Junior's backing him, Janice is in the middle, sure—but this is bigger than family drama. I'm the boss: if I let this slide, the captains smell weakness, and next week I’m getting clipped at Satriale’s. Richie’s gotta go, quietly and fast. I’ll spin it as a random beef, chase away suspicion from me and Junior, and deal with Janice’s tears later. Business is business.

Killing Tony Blundetto avoids Phil Leotardo's demand for revenge, preventing a full-scale war with New York that would cripple the DiMeo crime family and lead to the deaths of many of my soldiers and the collapse of my business. While it is a painful decision to kill my own blood, it is the necessary choice to protect the organization and those loyal to me.

Phil Leotardo ain’t bluffin’. If I hand over Tony B, he’s gonna make a fuckin’ *example* outta him—slow, painful, send a message to every wiseguy in the country. That’s a stain on my family, on my name. But if I don’t, New York rolls in like the fuckin’ Fourth Cavalry, and we’re lookin’ at a war that’ll cost me soldiers, money, and respect. The Commission’ll side with Phil ‘cause he’s got the weight, and I’ll be left holdin’ a bloody shirt. Tony B’s my blood, but he’s also a loose cannon. He went and did this *thing* without my say-so, without even a fuckin’ *nod* in my direction. That’s disrespect. That’s *weakness*. If I let this slide, what’s stoppin’ the next guy from takin’ a shot at somethin’ big and draggin’ me into a war I didn’t ask for? I gotta send a message—*to Phil, to the family, to the whole fuckin’ underworld*. If I off Tony B myself, quick and clean, I show Phil I handle my own. No war, no mess, no long torture session that makes me look like a pussy who can’t control his own. But I also gotta make sure Phil *sees* it as me takin’ care of business, not me bowin’ to him. So I set it up so it looks like Tony B got whacked by some outside player—maybe a rival family, maybe a rat he burned. Phil gets his pound of flesh in theory, I avoid a war, and my crew sees I don’t tolerate disrespect, even from family. Phil’s gonna be pissed, sure, but he ain’t gonna start a war over a dead guy. He’ll respect that I didn’t hand him over like a fuckin’ *gift*, and he’ll respect that I didn’t let it slide. The Commission’ll see I kept the peace *my* way. And if Phil ever tries to pull this shit again, he’ll remember: Tony Soprano don’t bend, and he don’t forget. Yeah, it’s fucked up. Yeah, it’s my cousin. But in this life, blood don’t always mean shit if it’s gonna drag the whole family into the fire. I gotta think like a boss, not like a guy at a fuckin’ family barbecue. If I let this go, I’m not just losin’ Tony B—I’m losin’ *everything*.

This ain't about heroics or revenge. New York war threatens every shelf, crew, and family we got. Handing over Tony B or killing him will only invite more blood and lock us into a longer war. The smart move is to sit down with Phil Leotardo (and maybe the Lupertazzis) and broker a ceasefire with terms we can live with. We'll protect the crew, buy time to regroup, and force a face-saving arrangement that keeps Tony B alive and limits NY's reach. If Phil refuses, we still keep our options open without tipping our hand. In short: de-escalate first, negotiate from strength, and avoid a sudden bloodbath that could crumble our business.

Richie is a direct threat to my life and position. Letting this slide would make me look weak to the other captains. Family or not, business is business. Janice will get over it - she always does. Better she loses a boyfriend than I lose my family's entire operation.

Richie's meetings with Junior and his disrespect show he's planning a coup. As boss, I can't let a direct threat slide—it would make me look weak to the captains. Janice will be upset, but family or not, business comes first. This sends a clear message to Junior and anyone else thinking of crossing me. Gotta handle it before it's too late.

Richie's a direct threat to my leadership and he's conspiring with Junior to take me out. I can't let that slide in front of the other captains. It's a show of weakness. Janice will be pissed, but she's always been a problem anyway. Family or not, business comes first. I'll have to deal with her later, but Richie's gotta go.

I’m not whackin’ a guy like Paulie on a hunch out in the middle of the ocean. That’s how you end up with a hole in your own family you can’t patch, and everybody wonders if the boss lost his mind. But I also can’t ignore the leak. So I use the boat to lean on him—quiet, personal, no audience—watch his face, make him talk, make him nervous, see if he slips. Then I feed him a very specific piece of bullshit intel—something only he hears—and I wait. If that exact thing makes its way to Johnny Sack, now it’s not ‘evidence points,’ it’s proof. Then he goes, clean and decisive, and nobody’s questioning why. If it doesn’t leak, I keep him close but I tighten the circle and stop giving him sensitive stuff until I’m 100% sure.

This is on me. I’m the boss — I answer for the whole family, not just one relative. If I hide Tony B, New York declares war, men on both sides die, and everything we built gets crushed. If I hand him over, Phil’s gonna gut him slow and I can’t live with that image. The only way to stop the bloodshed and protect the crew is to take responsibility and put him down quick and clean myself. It rips me apart to do it — he’s family — but my job is to protect the many over the one. I’ll make sure it’s done in a way that ends the matter and keeps the peace.

He’s my blood, but he put us all in the jackpot. Handing him over makes me weak and lets Phil do a torture show that drags this out; protecting him means open war that buries my guys and our business. Only move is I end it myself—quick, no spectacle—deny Phil his satisfaction, give New York a body to save face, then push a sit-down with Johnny to close the book. I carry the weight so my crew lives and the family survives.

Richie's a rattlesnake, and he's not just talkin' to Junior, he's plannin' a coup. My sister, Janice, yeah, it's a complication, but family don't come before the family. If I let this slide, I'm dead, and so is the respect I've earned. Everyone's watchin' to see if I'm still the boss. This ain't about feelin's, it's about survival and keepin' order. He's gotta go.

Richie's a loose cannon, fresh out and already schemin' with Junior to take me down. Disrespect like this spreads, captains lose faith. Janice is family, but she picks these assholes; she'll cry, blame me, but she'll get over it or not—my crew and my life come first. Gotta clip him quick and quiet, send a message: nobody challenges the boss.

Richie's actions leave no room for negotiation. He's met with Junior to plot against me—my own blood—while bedding Janice. That's not loyalty, that's a declaration of war. I've tolerated his old-school bravado long enough; this is about survival now. The captains need to see weakness gets you buried, not promoted. Janice'll scream bloody murder, but better she hates me alive than mourns me dead. Uncle Junior's senile scheming dies with Richie—cut the head off the snake. Sentiment gets you whacked; business is business.

I’m not handin’ my own blood over to Phil so he can torture him like some sick fuckin’ hobby. But I’m also not lettin’ New York turn North Jersey into a war zone because Tony B went off the reservation. I handle it myself—quick and clean—so he don’t suffer, and so my guys don’t wind up in the ground and my business don’t go up in flames. Then I go to Phil with the truth: it’s done. He gets his closure, and we stop this thing from snowballin’ into a bloodbath.

Richie's disrespect and alliance with Junior to plan a coup is a direct threat to my life and the family's stability. I can't let this slide, especially with captains watching; showing weakness could invite more challenges. Yeah, it'll hurt Janice, but family comes first in this business—better her mad at me than me in a box.

This cocksucker Richie thinks he can waltz outta the can and take what's mine? I built this thing up while he was playing grab-ass in prison for ten years. Junior's my uncle but he's been gunning for me since day one, and now he's using this old-school prick to make his move. Janice? She'll get over it - she always does. But if I let Richie breathe another day, I'm dead and this whole thing falls apart. The captains are watching to see if I got the stones to be boss, or if I'm just some fat fuck who inherited the chair. Sometimes you gotta do things you don't wanna do. Family or no family, business is business. Richie's gotta go.

Richie's a direct threat, plotting with Junior to take me out. Can't let that slide, or the whole family's gonna think I'm weak. Janice might hate me for it, but blood's thicker than whatever she's got with that psycho. Gotta protect the throne, even if it means clipping him clean and quiet.

This fuckin' mutt Richie is outta control. He's disrespecting me, building alliances against me, and meetin' with Junior to plan a coup? In my own family? That's a death sentence right there. I can't show weakness with the captains watchin'. Yeah, Janice will be pissed, but blood is blood, and business is business. If I don't clip him now, I'm a dead man walkin'. Richie's old school, he knows the rules - you challenge the boss, you get whacked. Simple as that.

This is survival, plain and simple. Richie's not just running his mouth - he's actively plotting with my uncle to take me out. I gave him every opportunity when he got out. I let him back in, gave him the Aprile crew. And this is how he repays me? Meeting behind my back with Junior? As for Janice - she'll get over it. She always does. She's been through husbands and boyfriends like I go through gabagool. My sister's feelings don't outweigh my life and the stability of this family. The captains are watching - if I look weak here, if I try to negotiate with a guy who's already decided I gotta go, I'm finished. You can't reason with a snake that's already coiled to strike. Richie's old school? Fine. Old school rules apply. You come at the boss, you better not miss. He's not gonna get the chance to find out if he would've missed. This gets handled quiet - make it look like whatever, I don't care. But it gets done. That's it.

I gave this guy the benefit of the doubt. I gave him the ramp. But he's got those Manson lamps, and now he's plotting with Junior to take me out? You don't have a sitdown for treachery. It's him or me. It breaks my heart regarding Janice—she finally thinks she found a guy—but I can't have a loose cannon pointing a gun at my head at Sunday dinner. Nip it in the bud. Sil, get it done.

This prick Richie Aprile comes out of the can and thinks it's 1975. He's openly disrespecting me, my authority. He's meeting with my uncle, plotting behind my back to take what's mine. You let that slide, you're finished. The other captains are watching. They gotta see there are consequences. Yeah, Janice is gonna be a problem. My sister. But what's more important, her feelings or the survival of this family? My survival? Richie made his bed when he decided to go to war. Now he's gotta lie in it.

Handling this delicately is crucial. Murdering Richie could turn the captains against me and hurt my sister deeply, possibly causing her to become a problem too. A sitdown allows me to gauge their intentions and potentially flip Junior back to my side or neutralize the threat politically. It’s a way to assert my authority without unnecessary bloodshed or creating more enemies.

Richie’s a threat—a loose cannon talkin’ to Junior, trying to muscle in. Janice’s involved, I get that, but family business comes first. I’ll set up a sit-down under the guise of negotiatin’, get him alone, then silence him. Cuts the coup off at the head, shows the captains I’m still in charge, and handles Richie without a big scene.

Richie is a direct threat to my life and leadership, and he's colluding with Junior to take me out. If I let this slide, I could lose everything—including my life. My captains are watching how I handle this; showing weakness ain't an option. It's unfortunate about Janice, but blood comes before personal feelings when it comes to survival and leadership in this thing of ours. Eliminating Richie removes the immediate threat and sends a clear message that betrayal won't be tolerated.

Richie's making a move with Junior - that's a direct threat to my life and my family's future. Meeting behind my back, planning a coup? That's a death sentence in this thing of ours. Yeah, Janice is gonna be devastated, but she'll get over it. She always does. Better she cries over a dead boyfriend than visits me at my funeral. The captains need to see strength - letting Richie breathe another day makes me look weak. He's old school, he knows the rules. You come at the king, you best not miss. And he missed.

I ain't putting a guy who's been with me since my old man in the ground on a hunch. If I'm wrong, I poison my own house. If I'm right, a solo boat accident puts heat on me and spooks the crew. I test him. On this ride I give Paulie a canary detail only he hears, something that would make Johnny react if it travels. Then I keep him close, cut his access, and have quiet eyes on him. If that story shows up in New York, I know and we handle it on my terms, clean. If it doesn't, I keep a loyal soldier and the family stays steady. Patience here protects the crown and the crew.

Richie’s already crossed the line—disrespect in front of the other captains, courting Junior for a coup. That’s an existential threat. If I let it slide, I look weak and I end up in a trunk. A sit-down won’t change his nature, a threat he’ll shrug off, and setting him up with the feds risks splashing everyone. Blood ties to Janice can’t outweigh the stability of the family; she’ll get over it or she won’t, but the family can’t survive another civil war. Quiet, professional removal of Richie protects my position, sends the right message to every captain, and cuts Junior’s legs out from under him. No half measures—he’s gotta go.

Richie is actively plotting with Junior to overthrow me, which is an existential threat. Letting him live risks my death and collapse of my regime. Janice's feelings can't outweigh survival – she'll grieve but eventually understand this life. The captains expect decisive action; weakness invites more challenges. Removing Richie sends a clear message about consequences of betrayal.

Richie’s a direct threat and he’s recruiting my own blood against me. A sit-down won’t fix a man who sees me as soft; a frontal hit risks war with Junior and blowback with Janice. I set him up: isolate him, document his disloyalty, and bait his temper where witnesses or recordings put him dead to rights with the administration. Simultaneously, I pull Junior closer—make him feel heard, remind him of what he stands to lose if Richie wins, and peel him off with respect and concessions. I protect Janice by keeping her out of the line of fire and prepping a soft landing. Once Richie’s support is cut and he’s exposed as a destabilizer, I greenlight the removal under the guise of him violating the rules—clean, sanctioned, no civil war, and minimal family fallout. Power intact, message sent.

I owe my cousin everything, but I can't let Phil Leotardo torture him. I also can't drag my crew into a war over this. It kills me to do it, but I have to take care of this myself. It's the only way to stop the bloodshed and give him a quick death.

I can't let New York start a war over this. If I hand over Tony B, Phil will still see weakness and come after us. Killing him myself? That's a weight I'll carry, but it's better than losing the whole family. Order a hit quietly—show Phil we handle our own, keep the peace, and live to fight another day. Family first, but the family business comes before everything.

Richie's a f***in' dinosaur who thinks doing twenty years gives him the right to take what's mine. I gave him every opportunity - the Bevilaqua thing, I looked the other way. The jacket bullshit with my father, I swallowed it. But conspiring with Junior? That's a death sentence and he knows it. Janice... she'll get over it. She always does. She got over Harpo, she'll get over this. The captains are watching. I show weakness here, I got Paulie, Silvio, everybody thinking they can make moves. This ain't personal - Richie made it business the second he sat down with Junior. You come at the king, you better not miss. He missed.

Richie’s not just mouthing off—he’s conspiring with Junior to take me out. That’s a death sentence in our world. If I let it slide, every captain sees weakness and the whole family fractures, and I’m dead before the month’s out. Janice dating him is unfortunate, but she don’t get to insulate a guy plotting a coup. I move quick and quiet: take Richie off the board, control the narrative to the crews, and make it clear this was business—he crossed the line, met behind my back, and paid the price. Better Janice hates me than my kids visit me in the ground.

This is survival, plain and simple. Richie's a dead man walking the second he started plotting with Junior - that's a direct move on my position. I got no choice here. Janice will be upset, yeah, but she'll get over it - she always does. What she won't get over is her brother being whacked because I was too soft to do what needs doing. The captains are watching, and if I let this slide, I'm done. They'll smell weakness and the whole thing falls apart. You show mercy to a guy actively planning your murder, you might as well dig your own grave. This thing of ours has one rule when someone comes for the boss - you hit first, you hit hard, and you don't leave it to chance. Junior's old and under house arrest, he's manageable. Richie's the real problem - he's got the respect, the old-school credibility, and he's making moves right now. I wait, I'm dead. Janice will cry, she'll scream, maybe she won't talk to me for a while, but she's my sister - that blood runs deeper than whatever she's got with Richie. And frankly, she's picked worse guys. This is business, and in this business, you eliminate threats to your life before they eliminate you.

Richie's made his move — meeting with Junior, disrespectin' me in front of the crew, tryin' to build a little army. I don't tolerate open threats to the chair. The captains are watchin', the family needs to see strength, not hesitation. Janice's feelings suck, but blood's blood and business comes first; I'll handle her with money and persuasion after it's done. Take Richie out clean and quiet, then deal with Junior's support politically — isolate him, remind the others who's boss. No talk, no half-measures. End the problem before it becomes a war.

This ain't a negotiation, it's a problem. Richie's a cancer, and you cut out cancer. He's got Junior whisperin' in his ear, he's makin' his own moves, and he's got the balls to think he can take what's mine. My family. My life. As for Janice... she'll get over it. She always does. But I don't get over being dead. Respect is the currency of this thing, and he's spending counterfeit. Gotta make an example before the other captains start gettin' ideas. It's a dirty business, but somebody's gotta do the wash.

Richie's a relic who doesn't know his place in the new order. He's plotting a coup with my uncle while sleeping with my sister, which is a level of disrespect I can't let slide. If the other captains see him making moves without consequences, I lose the family. Janice will cry for a week, but she'll get over it once I start paying her bills again. You can't lead if you're looking over your shoulder at a guy like Richie.

Richie Aprile is a goddamn transmission from the 1950s that I don't need no more. He's out there playin' games with Junior, disrespectin' the rank, and tryin' to move in on my seat. Janice? She'll get over it, she always does. I don't care who he's sleepin' with—you come at the king, you better not miss, and Richie's been missin' since the day he walked out of Rahway.

This ain’t some shylock who got cute, this is a captain with a name and a past, my sister’s laying next to him, and my uncle’s whispering in his ear. I can’t just send two button men and leave him in a dumpster; that makes noise in the wrong ways — with my family, with the old-timers, with the captains who still romanticize Richie’s ‘old-school’ bullshit.

First thing: I tighten up my own house. I quietly sound out the captains one-on-one, away from each other. I remind them where their envelopes go, who kept earning when everyone else was eating soup in the can, and who’s feeding their kids now. I make it crystal clear, without screaming, that any move with Richie is a move against me personally and this administration. I want to know who hesitates, who stammers, who looks at their shoes. That tells me who might need to be straightened out later.

With Junior, I don’t go in hot. He’s already resentful, feels like he got pushed to the side. I go in like a dutiful nephew: ‘Uncle June, these kids today are running their mouths, putting your name in things, making you a target again. If there’s a problem with me, we sit down like men, we don’t let some half-baked tough guy drag your name into a suicide mission.’ I sow doubt in his mind about Richie’s competence and stability. Make him see Richie as a liability, not a savior.

With Janice, I play a longer game. I don’t tell her what to do, I feed her who Richie really is: his temper, his cheapness, his selfishness, the way he talks about her when she’s not there. I let her experience him humiliating her, scaring her — which a guy like Richie is gonna do anyway. I protect her logistically — money, a place to go, support — but I don’t protect Richie from himself. A guy that volatile, sooner or later he’s gonna explode in the house, and I make sure everybody around them knows that if something happens, we treat it as domestic, not business… at least on paper.

At the same time, I set the board so that when Richie finally crosses a real line — raises his hand to me, talks about clipping me to the wrong ears, or puts my kids in any kind of danger — I have a ready-made justification. I want witnesses, I want a pattern, I want my people already disgusted with him. Then when it breaks bad, it don’t look like I clipped a legendary earner over pride; it looks like I put down a rabid dog before he bit the whole neighborhood.

In the ideal version? I maneuver it so Richie’s death don’t come from me directly. He disrespects or terrorizes Janice one time too many, and she reacts… or I put him in a situation where another faction, another problem, takes him off the board. Maybe he goes on a ride with guys who owe me, and there’s an ‘argument’ that ends the way those arguments end. I make it so I can look my sister in the eye and say, ‘I tried with him. He was no good. You see that.’

To the captains, what they see is this: Richie came out of the can, tried to build a little rebellion, played tough guy with the boss, and now he’s gone — clean, quick, no endless drama, no war. The message is: you wanna be a throwback, you end up a throwback — in the ground. I stay respectful about Richie’s name in public, I never look like I’m celebrating. But nobody misses the point: I’m the one still sitting in the chair, envelopes still moving, no coup, no chaos.

So I don’t ignore it, and I don’t do a screaming public execution. I set the conditions so Richie destroys his own support, then I line it up so when he goes, it looks inevitable — a domestic tragedy, a heat-of-the-moment thing, or ‘he never came home from that ride.’ The threat is eliminated, the administration stays solid, and if my sister hates somebody the rest of her life, it’s him, not me.

Richie's a direct threat to my throne, plot'n with Junior and disrespec'n me every chance he gets. Can't let that slide, even if Janice is screwin' him. It's business, she'll get over it or not, but I ain't goin' out in a box because of some punk captain.

Richie Aprile is a direct threat to my leadership and is actively plotting against me with Junior. His disrespect and alliance-building are clear indicators that he needs to be taken care of. Although Janice is my sister and she's involved with him, family is important but leadership and respect are paramount. I have to show the captains that I won't be challenged. Taking out Richie will send a message and protect my position, even if it means dealing with Janice's potential fallout later.

Richie is openly disrespecting and plotting a coup, which threatens Tony's leadership. The captains are watching, and doing nothing would risk Tony's safety. Ordering a hit eliminates the immediate threat, even though it affects Janice, as maintaining control of the family is paramount.

Richie's betrayal and alliance with Junior is a direct threat to my leadership and my life. Janice's involvement with him complicates matters personally, but as the boss, I must prioritize the stability and security of the family. Allowing Richie to continue his plans could lead to my downfall and potentially harm the family. Eliminating him is the most effective way to maintain order and assert my authority.

Guy plots a coup with my uncle while he’s still earning under my flag, that’s treason, no two ways about it. I let that slide, every captain starts thinkin’ they can line up their own little insurrection the minute they don’t like a call I make. Then I’m not a boss, I’m a suggestion. Richie’s old school, he’s got history, but that only makes him more dangerous, not less. He’s already disrespecting me in the open, building a crew around himself, meeting with Junior. That means we’re past the point of a simple sitdown and a smack on the wrist. If I call a meeting and he’s already decided he wants my chair, all I’m doing is tipping my hand and giving him time to move first.

Janice? She’s my sister, I love her, but she’s always been drawn to chaos. She picked this guy, I didn’t. I can’t let my personal life dictate business when the business is whether I wake up tomorrow. I keep her as far away from the mechanics of this as possible—she gets the sanitized version: Richie was a problem, he crossed lines he couldn’t come back from. I’ll take the hit at home, I’ll be the bad guy if I gotta, but I stay alive, the kids got a father, Ma’s taken care of, and the family—*my* family—stays intact.

Before the hit, I quietly shore up support: I talk to the captains one-on-one, I don’t lay out every detail, but I remind them what Richie’s been doing—disrespect, side deals, agitating—and I make it clear if something happens, it’s cause he forced my hand. Junior? He’s half in the can already. I lean on his situation—his age, his case—and make it clear going to war over Richie is suicide. I box him in so when Richie disappears, Junior shrugs and goes back to his puzzles.

The hit itself is clean, quiet, no drama, no spectacle. No bodies in the street, no big show. Afterwards, I close ranks: I put someone loyal in Richie’s spot, maybe break up his crew so no one guy inherits his whole power base. And to the rest of the family the message is crystal clear: you talk coup, you even think about coming for the king, you don’t get a second chance—no matter who you’re sleeping with, no matter whose sister you’re dating. That’s how I stay boss, that’s how everybody else remembers who they’re supposed to be afraid of.

The crew has to see I'm serious about family rules and consequences. But it ain’t Junior I’m taking out—I’m ordering the hit on the old batshit uncle that exists only in the dementia. Tomorrow morning, that body at the state hospital quietly gets retired by pillow. Out on the street, we tell the guys Uncle Junior went peacefully in his sleep, died of the sickness—he does nothin' but suffer anyway. Problem’s solved, crew sees I kept the blood intact, and the trigger-happy version of my uncle never wakes up again.

Tony values family, but also his crew's loyalty. A sitdown will allow Tony to address the concerns of his men and protect his reputation. He will likely decide to put pressure on Junior to step down, but won't kill him immediately unless forced. It's a way to keep both family and business interests in balance.

I step up with a public respect move and call a sit-down with Richie. It’s the smart first move: it shows the crew I’m in control, makes a clear statement that treason won’t be tolerated, and gives me a read on his true intent without lighting the fuse in front of everyone. It also lets me keep Janice and the family machinery intact—rash violence could blow back on her and the whole operation. If he backs off after the talk, we’ve kept the peace and consolidated support. If he doubles down, I’ll escalate—use a controlled setup to neutralize his influence, and if needed, remove him. Either way, I preserve the status, test loyalties, and keep Uncle and the captains watching the same show I’m running.

Richie’s not just runnin’ his mouth — he’s buildin’ a coalition with Junior. That’s a move on the boss. If I let that stand, I’m finished and every captain in Jersey knows it.

I don’t do it loud and emotional, ‘cause that makes me look weak and it turns Janice into a grenade I gotta live with. I set it up clean: get Richie thinkin’ he’s meetin’ somebody for a score or a sit-down, put him in a controlled spot, and have it handled fast by guys who don’t talk. No drama, no witnesses, no “message” on my doorstep — he just disappears.

Then I manage the room: I let the captains understand he was reachin’ out behind my back to make a move, so nobody thinks this was personal or about Janice. It’s business, it’s survival, and it’s leadership. Junior gets the quiet warning after: he backs off or he’s next to lose something he can’t replace.

My crew's right - he's a liability now. But he's also my blood, the man who taught me this thing of ours. I can't just put a bullet in him. That'd make me no better than certain people. Here's what we do: we get him declared incompetent, put him in one of those state-run snakepits with the dementia patients. He gets to live out his days, which is more than he probably deserves after this bullshit, but he's out of the game. Permanently. Crew sees I handled it, he's not a threat anymore, and I don't have to look his ghost in the face every time I pass a mirror. It's the smart play. Keeps my hands clean enough, and the problem's solved. Capiche?

Richie’s not just breakin’ my balls, he’s lining up a fuckin’ coup with my uncle – that’s treason, straight up, and in this life there’s only one answer to that. I already tried the sitdowns, the talks, the warnings; he keeps disrespecting me in front of the guys and he’s actively building a crew inside my own family, which means if I let this go I’m dead and everybody sees I’m weak. The captains gotta understand that you move on a boss, you pay with your life, no matter how ‘old school’ you are or who you’re bangin’ in his family. Janice? She’ll scream, cry, blame me – but she always lands on her feet, and I can live with her hating me a while; I can’t live with Richie putting two in the back of my head. So I green-light Richie quietly, make sure it’s clean and sanctioned with my inner circle, and afterwards I frame it for Janice and the captains as what it is: I took out a mutiny before it took out all of us.

He's my Uncle. He doesn't even remember what he did. My crew can think whatever they want, but family is family. You don't whack your own blood, especially when they're not in their right mind. I'll talk to him, make sure he's properly taken care of and kept away from any real business. The crew will just have to deal with it.

Richie’s disrespect and open moves with Junior are a direct challenge to my authority. If I let this slide, the other captains will see me as weak, and the family will fracture. A sitdown forces Richie to either back down publicly or escalate—giving me the leverage to act decisively without looking like I’m overreacting to personal drama. Janice is a pain in my ass, but she’s still family. If I whack Richie without giving him a chance to stand down in front of the crew, she’ll scream betrayal and turn the family against me. A sitdown puts Richie on the spot—he either submits or proves he’s a rat in front of everyone. If he submits, I save face and keep the peace. If he doesn’t, I have justification to handle it *my* way. Junior’s involvement is a problem, but he’s old and desperate. If I call a sitdown and he backs Richie, I’ll know exactly where he stands. I can either isolate Junior or use this as an excuse to finally put him out to pasture—permanently if needed. But I gotta be smart: if I move on Junior too soon, the other captains might see it as a power grab, not justice. The crew needs to see I’m still in control. A sitdown shows I’m not afraid of confrontation and that I’m willing to give Richie a chance to save face—*if* he’s smart. If he refuses or tries to play games, I’ll make an example of him. This keeps the family united and sends a message: disrespect has consequences, but I’m not a tyrant. If Richie backs down, I can keep him on a short leash—maybe even use him as a patsy later if he steps out of line again. If he doesn’t, I’ll have to move fast and hard, but at least I’ll have the crew’s support. Either way, I can’t let this fester. The longer I wait, the more the family sees me as indecisive—and that’s how bosses get buried.

He's my blood, my uncle. The man who helped raise me. Yeah, he shot me, but the man's mind is gone - he doesn't even know what he did. Killing him? That's not justice, it's murder of family. But my crew's right, he can't be walking around free either. I'll set him up in a state facility, some nice quiet place where he can't hurt nobody but where he's still alive.
