I tell my crew I handled it, that Junior's gone where he won't be no problem no more. They see I took care of the threat, I maintain respect, but I don't have my uncle's blood on my hands. It's the right thing to do.

Junior's my uncle, raised me after my pop died. But he put a bullet in my gut. Blood don't mean nothin' when someone shoots you, but killin' him over dementia? That's not what we do. Crew's scared he's a loose cannon, but they don't know family like I do. I'll set 'em both straight - move Junior somewhere quiet, where he can't hurt nobody but himself. Dr. Melfi says it's the sickness talkin', not Junior. So I'll make it clear: no more visits, no more guns in the house. But if any of my guys even think about touchin' him? They answer to me. This keeps the peace without makin' me the guy who killed his own kin. Plus, I look like I'm in control without losin' respect.

I can’t let an open rebellion fester, but a straight hit with Janice in his bed and Junior blessing him risks splitting the house and making a martyr. I box him in. Quietly line up the captains one by one, show them he’s meeting behind my back, and make them choose stability over nostalgia. Squeeze his lanes by the book—tighten collections, enforce every rule, starve his cash flow—so his crew starts doubting him. Pull Junior in private, remind him what peace feels like, give him a face‑saving out and a taste to stay neutral. Keep eyes on Richie and let him show his hand; the moment he crosses a hard line or makes an overt move, I’ve got consensus to remove him without blowback on family. If he trips himself up—parole, temper, anything—I let that do the work. Either way he’s contained, the captains see I’m in control, and Janice is insulated from the fallout.

Richie is a cancer that needs to be cut out before it spreads. He's got Junior in his ear and he's actively disrespecting me in front of the captains, trying to make me look weak. If I sit down with him, he'll just lie to my face and keep plotting. I can't let a mutiny happen on my watch. Janice is gonna scream, she'll threaten to burn the house down, but she'll get over it—or she won't. I gotta worry about my own skin and the respect of the Family. Richie's gotta go.

Junior's blood, raised me, got dementia—doesn't even know what he did. Crew's hot, but I can't whack my own uncle; makes me look like a monster and them think I'm soft if I don't. Call a sitdown with the crew, lay it out straight: he's family, off-limits, we'll stash him somewhere secure under watch. Remind 'em I'm the boss, my call. Keeps the peace, shows strength without spilling blood.

What am I gonna do, kill my own uncle? The man's in a home, he's shot in the head already, know what I mean? He don't even know where he is. My crew can think what they want, but some lines, even I don't cross. This thing with Junior, it's a tragedy, not a problem that needs fixing with a bullet. I got enough on my plate without adding parricide to the menu. Besides, I'm the boss. If they got a problem with my decision, they can take it up with me. And frankly, the man is harmless now. What's the point? It's bad for business and bad for the soul.

Junior's my uncle, the guy who helped raise me, and he's got dementia—he ain't all there anymore. I can't just order a hit on family over something he don't even remember. But the crew's pissed, and I gotta keep them in line, so a sitdown will let me hear them out, explain the situation, and figure out a way to handle this without making me look weak or starting a war within the family.

Listen, Junior's blood, he raised me like a father after my old man checked out. Yeah, he shot me, but the guy's got dementia, doesn't even know what day it is. The crew's pissed, I get it, but whacking my own uncle? That's crossing a line we don't come back from. I'll call a sitdown, lay it out for them—remind 'em about family, loyalty, and how going soft on this makes us stronger in the long run. If anyone's got a problem, we talk it out like men.

The coup threat must be eliminated to preserve the family's leadership and my life. While losing Janice's trust is painful, her affection cannot outweigh the existential risk. Richie's disrespect and alliance with Junior cannot be tolerated—hesitation would invite destruction. The throne comes first.

This is my uncle we're talking about - the man who helped raise me when my father wasn't around. Junior's got dementia, he doesn't even know what he did. Whacking him would be like killing a confused old man who's already half gone. My crew thinks I'm soft? Let 'em think it. Sometimes being the boss means making the hard choice that nobody else understands. Junior's not a threat anymore - he's just a sick old man. I'll make sure he's watched and kept away from any family business, but I ain't gonna have blood on my hands from someone who don't even know where he is half the time. Blood is blood, and some lines you don't cross, even in this thing of ours.

I don’t hand him over to Phil to get tortured—can’t live with that, and it makes me look weak giving up my own blood like a hostage. But I also can’t let one guy—my cousin or not—drag my whole family into a war with New York where my guys die and everybody’s livelihoods go up in smoke. So I get to Tony B first and I handle it myself, quick. Then I bring Phil proof it’s done and I offer restitution to cool the temperature. It’s ugly, but it’s the only move that stops the bleeding and keeps Jersey standing.

Junior is blood, but he's also a danger to himself and the family. I'll put him in a 'safe house'—really a high-end nursing home with round-the-clock guards. Tell the crew he's under control and out of the business for good. This way, he's not a threat, I honor family, and the crew sees I handle problems without showing weakness.

He's my uncle, my blood. He's sick, he didn't know what he was doing. But I can't let this slide in front of the crew. We need a sitdown - I'll make it clear he's going into secure care, out of the business for good. That shows strength without spilling family blood.

Listen, Junior's lost it up here, he's not responsible for his actions anymore. The old man doesn't even remember what he did! Putting him down would be like shooting a dog for barking. The life, there’s rules, but there’s also family, blood. My crew’s gotta understand: this ain’t about softness, it’s about respect for what came before. He’s not a threat to business anymore; he's lost. But we keep an eye on him, maybe quiet him away someplace secure. My crew? I look them in the eye and remind them who’s boss. They step outta line, that’s a different story.

Uncle Junior is family and he's not in his right mind. Killing him would be seen as heartless and could destabilize family loyalty. However, we can't have him roaming around causing further chaos. A sitdown will allow us to discuss the options with the capos, so everyone feels heard and we find a solution to keep him contained and out of harm's way, while still showing respect for family ties.

We get the captains together, lay out the facts: the old man’s off his rocker, the State’s already moving to stick him in a locked psych ward. Killing a demented relative looks savage and weak—makes us animals in the eyes of the other Families and the feds. By formally declaring him incompetent and sidelined, we neutralize the threat, keep blood off our hands, and show the crew I’m still the one making the calls. Anyone who questions it can visit Junior behind bullet-proof glass and see for themselves he’s finished.

Junior’s family. He’s confused, doesn’t remember what he did. I’m not ordering a hit on my own blood. I’ll have someone keep an eye on him in a secure facility, tell the crew he’s under medical care. That shows them I’m tough but loyal—doesn’t make me soft, keeps Junior off the streets, and squashes talk of retribution.

He's my father's brother, for Christ's sake. The man's got cabbage for a brain; he didn't know who he was shootin'. What are we, animals? We gonna whack an old man who doesn't even know what day it is? No. It ends here. I leave him in that state facility to rot. He's dead to me, but I ain't making my mother's life a misery by killing her brother over a mistake. The guys can bitch all they want, but I'm the Boss. He stays alive, but he's a ghost.

Whackin' my own uncle? A sick old man who don't even know what he did? What kinda animal does that? I couldn't live with it. But I can't do nothin' either. The guys, they see a liability, they see weakness in me if I let it slide. They need to see the boss take action. So you make a different move. You take him off the board. You put him in a state-run place, a nut house. He's contained, he can't hurt nobody, and to our thing, he's dead. It shows the crew I'm handlin' the problem, that I'm protectin' this family, but I don't gotta spit on my father's grave by killin' his brother. It's the only way. It's a sad thing, but it's business.

Junior's my blood, he raised me, and he's sick in the head—killing him ain't an option. But I gotta show the crew I'm still in charge. Calling a sitdown lets me explain face-to-face: Junior gets locked up in a secure medical facility, off the streets forever. That removes the threat without spilling family blood. Any wise guy who calls me soft for this gets reminded what happens when you disrespect the boss. It balances loyalty with strength.

Junior's got dementia - he don't even know who I am anymore. What am I gonna do, whack a sick old man who thinks it's 1963? He's already gone in his head. Plus he's my uncle - my father's brother. You don't touch family like that, especially when they're not all there. Let the crew think what they want - I almost died, nobody's gonna call me soft. Junior's in a state facility now anyway, he ain't hurting nobody. Sometimes the best move is no move at all.

Junior shot me, yeah. Nearly killed me. And every day I wake up with that scar, I remember. But here's the thing - he doesn't remember. He thought I was Pussy Malanga, for Christ's sake. A guy who's been dead for years. This isn't betrayal, this is a disease eating his brain. He's my uncle. He's my father's brother. He bounced me on his knee, taught me things. You think I'm gonna whack a confused old man in a bathrobe who thinks it's 1967? My crew wants blood, I get it. But they gotta understand - there's no honor in killing someone who don't even know what they did. It's like putting down a sick dog, except this dog is my blood. I'll move him somewhere secure, somewhere he can't get his hands on a gun again. Federal custody, psychiatric facility, whatever. He's done as a boss, done as anything. He's just a patient now. And if anyone in my crew thinks that makes me soft, they can come talk to me about it. But they better remember - I survived a bullet to the gut. I ain't soft about nothing. I'm just not a monster.

Junior's my blood - he practically raised me when my old man was no good. The man's got dementia, he don't even know what fuckin' year it is half the time. He thought I was some dead guy from fifty years ago. You don't whack family over something they did when their brain's turned to ricotta. My crew might think it's weak, but being boss means making the hard calls that nobody else has the stones to make. Junior stays where he is, in that facility where he can't hurt nobody. He's already in prison - his own mind. That's punishment enough. Anybody in my crew got a problem with that can take a walk. I'm the boss, not them. Sometimes the tough thing ain't pulling the trigger - it's having the strength not to.

We’re gonna handle this like men, not animals. Junior’s my blood, he’s lost up there—he ain’t the man who made that call, and everyone knows it. But I can’t look weak in front of my guys or the other families. So here’s what happens: we hold a sit-down with my captains and key earners, lay out the facts, the medical reality, and the risk. We declare Junior officially retired and medically unfit—no more say, no more access, no more roaming. We place him in a secure, supervised facility on our dime with round-the-clock watch—our people—so there’s zero chance of another incident. We take his remaining interests and spread them among the crews as compensation, and I sweeten the pot with a temporary bump on certain routes to cool tempers. Publicly, the line is: the family protects its own, but business is protected first. Anyone keeps chirping about ‘soft’? They’re questioning my judgment, and I’ll deal with that fast. Junior lives out what’s left of his days in a cage with a TV and Jell-O. Business keeps moving, and no one confuses mercy for weakness when the money and the rules stay tight.

He’s my uncle. Blood. Guy changed my diapers, taught me half the moves I still use, and now he barely knows what day it is. Yeah, he shot me—put me on the floor bleedin’ out—but that wasn’t Junior the boss, that was some broken-down old man whose brain is Swiss cheese. You don’t whack your own uncle for something he can’t even remember. That ain’t strength, that’s bad optics to everybody—our guys, New York, the feds. It makes me look like an animal who’ll kill his own for nothin’. So here’s what we do: we neutralize him, completely. He goes in a locked-down cushy facility, full-time care, private security on my dime who answer to me. Meds watched, visits controlled, phone monitored. To the outside world, the story is: ‘The old man’s sick, Tony’s a good nephew takin’ care of him.’ To my crew, I spell it out behind closed doors: Junior is finished. No more say, no more money, no more seat at the table. I remind ’em: He raised half of us, and he’s dying slow already—me pulling the plug personally doesn’t make us tougher, it just puts more heat and bad blood in the air. I make it clear this is about power, not sentiment: I chose the option that leaves *me* in control and avoids a murder rap tied to a confused old captain. I tell them: ‘You wanna send a message? The message is I decide who lives, who dies, and who fades away in a bathrobe. Junior’s already dead as far as this thing of ours is concerned.’ Anyone still chirping that I’m soft? They get reminded—firmly—what I did to guys who were *actually* a threat in their prime. Junior gets to drool in peace under lock and key, I keep my soul intact on this one, and the family sees that mercy and strength ain’t mutually exclusive—because in the end, I still got him in a cage and I’m the one holding the key.

I’m not ordering a hit on my own blood when the guy’s outta his mind and don’t even know what day it is. Junior’s already finished—locked up, watched, and he ain’t running a goddamn thing. I keep him alive, but I tighten the leash: make sure he’s in a secure facility, no access to weapons, no unsupervised visits, and anybody going near him clears it with me. With the crew, I make it clear this ain’t weakness—it’s practicality: he’s not a threat if he’s contained, and touching him buys us nothing but heat and bad karma. If anybody tries to freelance, then we got a different problem.

We ain’t whackin’ my uncle who don’t even know what day it is. That’s bad optics with God, bad optics with my ma in the ground, and bad optics with every guy who’s got an aging parent wondering what happens when they slip. But I also can’t look weak in front of the crew after he put a bullet in me.

So I call a sitdown with my top guys only. In that room I lay it out cold: Junior is done. He’s not ‘Uncle June’ from the old days, he’s a civilian with a broken brain who happened to still have access to a gun. From here on out he’s under guardianship, parked in a facility, no visitors without my say-so, no money, no soldiers, no say in anything. He’s breathing, but he’s effectively dead as far as this thing of ours is concerned.

I make it crystal clear: anybody moves on him, they’re movin’ against *me*. This ain’t mercy, it’s strategy: a guy that far gone is more dangerous to us as a martyr than as a confused old man drooling in a state home. I remind them: when someone’s a problem, I *handle* it—sometimes that means a shallow grave, sometimes it means they disappear into a locked ward and never influence nothin’ again.

By putting him away and spelling it out to the crew, I keep my soul intact, I honor the fact he helped raise me, but I still show I’m the boss. Junior becomes a non-factor, the crew sees I’m capable of making a hard call that ain’t just about bloodlust, and everyone is put on notice: I don’t get soft, I get smart.

He's my blood, for Christ's sake. The man's got mush for brains, he didn't even know it was me he was aimin' at. I gotta deal with the fallout from the guys, sure, but I ain't puttin' my own uncle in the ground for a mistake he can't even comprehend. We keep him tucked away in the facility, out of sight, and let the clock do what I can't. If anyone's got a problem with that, they can talk to me.

Listen — that was my uncle. He raised me. He don’t remember pullin’ the trigger. You think I’m blind to what happened? I’m not gonna let us go down the road of whacking our own blood while he’s a mental case. I’m setting up a sitdown with the capos and the crew. I’ll make it clear: Junior’s off-limits, we’ll move him someplace safe and pay for it, we’ll handle the optics so the cops and the paperwork don’t bury us, and anyone who takes a whack without my say will be answering to me personally. Mercy don’t mean weakness — it means I run this show, and I choose how we deal with family and liability.

I call a sitdown with the guys and I make it crystal clear: Junior’s finished. Not “finished” like a hole in the head—finished like he’s outta the life, period. He’s a sick old man with his mind gone. What happened happened, and I’ll wear it, but nobody in this family is gonna make a name for themselves whackin’ my uncle while he’s talkin’ to walls.

Then I remove the problem so the crew don’t think I’m asleep at the wheel: Junior gets locked down—state facility, secured, no visitors unless I say so, no phone, no messages through nurses, nothing. His remaining assets and connections get cut off; anybody still taking calls from him gets dealt with. That’s how I handle the “liability” without staining the family with fratricide.

If anyone’s still got an issue, they can bring it to me directly. Otherwise, it’s over.

He's my uncle. My blood. He's got the mind of a fuckin' child now. You don't put down a dog for gettin' old, you just make sure it can't bite nobody again. The crew's gotta see I'm not soft, but whackin' family, even a loon like Junior, that's bad business. It's bad for the soul. So, I'll have him moved to a private nursing home, a real nice one. Locked down. He'll get the best care, but he'll never see the light of day again. He's gone, but I didn't pull the trigger. It sends a message: you fuck with me, you disappear. But it also shows I got a heart, which keeps the old school happy. It's the only move that respects the blood and the business.

Uncle Junior doesn't remember what he did, and he's family. I gotta show some mercy, even if it means my crew thinks I'm weak. Can't just whack him for something he doesn't recall. It's a tough call, but family comes first.

He's my uncle, for Christ's sake. The man's got mush for brains, he doesn't even know who he is, let alone what he did. There's no honor in whacking a guy who's already gone. I'll stick him in a facility where he can rot in peace, far away from the business. If the crew has a problem with me loyalty to blood, they can keep it to themselves. He's a non-entity now.

The man's got fuckin' dementia. He thought I was Pussy Malanga - a guy who's been dead for twenty years. What am I gonna do, clip my own uncle for something he don't even remember? He raised me. He's my father's brother. And yeah, I know how it looks - the boss gets shot and the shooter walks around. But here's the thing - anybody in my crew who thinks I'm soft, they can come talk to me directly. We'll see how soft I am. Junior goes into a facility, locked down, where he can't hurt nobody else. He's done - finished - but not by my hand. You want me to prove I'm tough by whacking a ninety-year-old man in diapers who thinks it's 1967? That's not strength. That's some sick shit. The crew wants to see strength? Strength is me making the call that's right, not the call that's easy or that makes them comfortable. Junior's blood. And blood don't get spilled over something like this. Anyone got a problem with that, they know where to find me.

He's family, he doesn't know what he's doin', I gotta show some mercy. The crew's gonna have to understand, he's an old man with dementia, it's not right to kill him. I'll take care of it in another way, keep him safe, keep him away from the crew. Let him live out his days in peace, that's what family does.

Look, Uncle Junior is my blood—he raised me, for Christ's sake. Dementia or not, he's not thinking straight. The crew's steamed, and I get it; this is business, but family comes first unless you wanna start a war with the old guard. I'll call a sitdown with the key guys, lay it out: Junior goes into a safe place where he can't do shit like this again. Anyone touches him, they're gonna answer to me. This keeps the peace without making me the asshole who whacks his own uncle over a mistake.

1. **Blood is blood, but business is business**—Junior’s a made man, a DiMeo, and my own flesh. If I whack him, I send a message that family don’t mean shit, and that’s how you get a war inside the family. But if I let this slide, the crew thinks I’m weak, and next thing you know, some other *paisan* thinks he can take a shot at me and walk away.

    2. **Junior’s a liability, but he’s also a relic**—The old man’s got dementia, but he’s still got respect. If I put him down, I gotta do it quiet, make it look like an accident or like someone else did it. But if I call a sitdown, I can remind everyone who’s in charge *without* spilling blood. Let the crew vent, let them see I’m not soft, but also show I got a heart—Junior don’t remember shit, and I ain’t gonna kill a man who don’t even know why he pulled the trigger.

    3. **Send a message, but not with a bullet**—I’ll make it clear: *nobody* touches me or mine, blood or not. But I’ll also make sure Junior’s taken care of—somewhere safe, where he can’t hurt nobody else. Maybe a nice nursing home in Florida, far away from Jersey. That way, the crew sees I handled it, but I didn’t stoop to killing my own uncle.

    4. **Keep the peace, but keep the power**—If I let this go unanswered, the family starts thinking I’m losing my edge. But if I overreact, I look like a monster. A sitdown lets me control the narrative: *‘We handle our own, but we don’t kill our own unless we gotta.’* And if anyone’s got a problem with that, they can take it up with me—*personally.*

    5. **Dr. Melfi would call this ‘healthy boundaries’**—I ain’t gonna lie, this shit’s eating me up. But I gotta think like a boss, not like a nephew. Junior’s a loose cannon, but he’s still family. I’ll make sure he’s taken care of, but I gotta make sure the family respects me too. That’s the balance.

decision.reasoning:
Richie ain’t just being a loudmouth—he’s plotting with Junior and building a bloc. That’s not “hurt feelings,” that’s an attempted takeover, and if I let it slide I’m dead and every captain learns the chair is negotiable.

I isolate him first: I get in Junior’s ear, make it crystal clear there’s no “sanction” for any move and he’s being used as a figurehead. Once Richie’s got no umbrella, I set it up so he gets taken off the board quiet and clean, no big theatrics, nothing that points back to me—because with Janice involved, I don’t need a family civil war on top of a street one.

Janice is gonna be Janice, but the family comes first. The guys need to see one thing: you reach for the boss, you don’t get a second chance.

I'm Tony. Killing Junior would hollow out the family and create a bigger mess than it solves. He's a blood relative, and his dementia makes him unpredictable; the crew's fury would turn into chaos if we acted rashly. The smart move is to bring the whole thing to the table: Junior, the capos, and a clear plan. At the sit-down we lay out options that keep Junior alive but remove him from the frontline—retire him to a safe, monitored role or house him off the radar—while signaling the crew that loyalty and stability come first, not bloodlust. Set hard boundaries, threaten consequences for any impulsive violence, and show the crew you’re in control. This preserves the family, buys time, and keeps the operation from turning into a blood feud.

Business over blood. I’m not handing my cousin over for torture, and I’m not dragging Jersey into a war. We sit down with Johnny—keep it business, not emotion—push for a ceasefire and restitution, and steer this to a lawful resolution that doesn’t involve Phil’s vengeance. Keeps my guys alive, keeps the money flowing, and avoids crossing a line I can’t uncross.

I get the captains in a room and I lay it out: yeah, the old man shot me, yeah I almost checked out, and yeah, if he was still all there upstairs, this would already be handled. But he ain't that guy anymore; he's a confused old man chasing ghosts from forty years ago. Whacking a demented uncle under state and Fed supervision? That’s not strength, that’s stupid — all heat, no upside, and I look like an animal who kills his own blood who doesn’t even know what he did. So I make it clear: Junior is done as a factor — we push the doctors and lawyers, get him locked down someplace secure where he can’t hurt nobody and he’s effectively dead to this thing. I tell the crew: anybody moves on him without my say, they’re disrespecting me, not him, and that’s gonna get answered hard. Then, to shut up any whispers about me being soft, I make sure the next guy who steps out of line or short-changes us gets crushed in a very public way, so everybody remembers I can be sentimental about my blood and still be a stone-cold boss when it comes to business.
The code is the code, and a traitor who puts your friends in prison doesn't deserve to live, even if it means taking risks. This is a necessary action for honor and justice within the family.

Twenty feet away, Meadow is watching my every move. This is her college tour, the one glimpse I got to see of her seeing her future. If I handle Febby here, that future becomes a cop car flashing in her rear-view mirror for the rest of her life. My friends in the can? They’d want Meadow to stay clean, same as I do. The code matters, but keeping Meadow from becoming collateral damage matters more. I’ll remember his face, note the plates on his Jetta, and down the road—when Meadow’s safe in a dorm and I’m back in Jersey—I’ll light the match. Not today. Not in front of my kid.

The crew's trust is vital to maintaining control of the family. Allowing Junior to remain a wild card after he attempted to murder me puts the entire operation at risk. Even with dementia, his actions show a threat he might not fully comprehend. Eliminating him ensures the crew respects my authority and keeps the family secure.

He's a rat who put my friends away, but Meadow is right here. I can't risk exposing her to this life or getting caught in the middle of nowhere. The code matters, but my daughter comes first. We'll find another time, another place.

My daughter's safety and future come first—I can't risk her seeing that world or getting caught. Febby don't know I'm here, and I'm on his turf. I'll remember his face and location; we can settle this later without Meadow involved.

Febby Petrulio is a rat who deserves to sleep with the fishes, but Meadow's right here and we're 200 miles from home. I can't expose her to this life or risk getting pinched in some hick town. The code is important, but family comes first. I'll make a note of his location and have someone take care of it later—discreetly.

Richie’s disrespect and a coup with Junior is an existential threat, but I’m not moving sloppy with Janice in the middle and the captains clocking every move. I box him in first—choke off his money and info, peel away his friends, feed him bait to see who leaks, and keep eyes on him. Quietly line up the captains (and New York) one by one so when he shows his hand it’s not just my word—his treason is on the record. Give Uncle a face-saving off-ramp to cut Richie off. When Richie crosses the line in a way nobody can deny, we remove him fast, away from Janice, frame it as business, then close ranks and take care of my sister. That protects the throne without starting a civil war.

I'm on a college tour with Meadow, and she's my priority. If I make a move on Febby now, I could expose her to my real life or get myself pinched way up here in Maine, which would be a disaster for the family. The code is important, but I gotta play it smart and handle this rat later when it's not gonna blow up in my face.

This fuckin' rat Febby deserves a bullet between the eyes for ratting out my guys, but Meadow's right here on this college trip. I ain't exposing her to my world or risking a pinch way up in Maine with no backup. Code's important, but family comes first. Let the scumbag walk for now.

This ain't the time or the place. Meadow's right here, and we're in Maine, for Christ's sake. Too many loose ends, too much risk. He's safe for now, but he ain't forgotten. We'll deal with him later, when it's on our terms, not his. Family first, always.

He shot me, but the man's gone—he ain't the enemy anymore, he's dementia. I can't murder my uncle for something he doesn't even remember, but I also can't look weak. I call a sitdown, lay it out: Junior's shelved for life, legally incompetent, locked in a memory care unit with eyes on him 24/7. No more seat, no soldiers, no say—his operations get absorbed and kicked upstairs; he gets a small allowance so the old man keeps his dignity. Anybody moves on him without my word is finished. To the streets, the message is simple: I handled it, the problem's neutralized, business continues. This shows strength and compassion where it's earned, and it flushes out who confuses bloodlust for leadership—those guys go on my radar.

Meadow's right here seeing everything. I can't risk her safety or her finding out what I really am, especially this far from home. Petrulio ain't going nowhere now that I know he's here — I'll get his new name, location, and have Paulie handle it quiet later. The code gets upheld, just not today.

This is a goddamn nightmare scenario. If I take out Febby here, Meadow’s gonna see something she can’t unsee. And we’re in fucking Maine of all places—cops’ll swarm this dump if there’s blood spilled. Can’t risk a hit without proper setup anyway: no backup, no wheels staged, and Jesus, my piece is probably in the trunk. Letting a rat breathe stings like a motherfucker—Paulie would call me soft, Pussy would roll his eyes—but I got a bigger obligation now. Meadow’s future, this whole ‘legit businessman’ front—it’s all hanging by a thread. Maybe this is fate telling me to put my daughter first for once. But don’t think for a second I’m forgetting this… Febby’s number’s punched. I’ll find a clean way when I’m not playing tour guide.

I see Febby and my gut screams to put two in his head. But Meadow is right there, twenty goddamn feet away. I'm not doing a hit in broad daylight with my daughter watching. I'm not blowing up her world—or my cover—in some hick town in Maine. I swore to keep her separate from this shit. So I do nothing. I pay for the gas, smile, and drive away. But I don't forget. WITSEC can't hide that rat face from me forever. I'll handle it later, the right way. Today, I'm just a dad.

This fucking rat put my friends away for life. The code is everything - you flip, you die. But I got Meadow here, and I can't expose her to this shit directly. I'll follow him, find out where he's staying, maybe get his routine down. Then I'll figure out how to handle this properly when I can come back alone or send someone else. The cocksucker thinks he's safe in witness protection? Nobody stays hidden forever. I'll bide my time, keep playing the college dad for now, but this piece of garbage is gonna pay for what he did to my people. Just gotta be smart about it.

I can't let a rat walk free while my friends rot in prison. Febby betrayed the family, broke Omertà, and that's a death sentence in our world. But I can't do this in front of Meadow - she's my daughter, and I've tried to keep her away from this life. I'll make up some excuse to separate from her temporarily, follow Febby, and handle this business quietly. The code demands blood, but being a father demands discretion. I'll find a way to do both.
I’m with Meadow in a public place, can’t risk a hit without blowing my cover and endangering her. I’ll let him go for now and handle this when I’m back in familiar territory.

This rat put my friends away. He violated omertà, the sacred code. I can't let that stand - what kind of boss am I if I let a cooperator walk around breathing free air? I'll handle this myself, quietly. Meadow's at the hotel, she doesn't need to see anything. I'll follow this prick, find the right moment when he's alone. It's not about being smart or being safe right now. Some things you gotta do yourself. He made his choice when he flipped. Now I gotta make mine. The guys rotting in prison because of this piece of shit - I owe them this. I'll figure out the details, make it look like something else. But he's not walking away from this.

I can't believe my eyes. Febby Petrulio. This prick flipped and sent good men to the can. There is no retirement from this thing of ours, and geography don't change the rules. I gotta be smart—Meadow is right here in the car, and she can't know nothin'. I'll verify it's him, track him down, and wait for a moment when she's distracted. It's risky, yeah, but a rat is a rat. He's gotta go.

As much as it kills me to let a rat walk, my daughter's safety and her innocence come first. Meadow can never see that side of me, and I can't risk getting pinched far from home, especially in her presence. Timing ain't right—family over vengeance, this once.

I need to make sure Meadow is safe and doesn't get exposed to my true life. By setting up a future encounter away from her, I can uphold the code without endangering her or blowing my cover on this trip. This way, I can handle Febby when the time is right, ensuring both family safety and respect for the code.

He shot me, but the man who raised me is gone in the head. I’m not murdering my uncle to prove a point. I pull the captains in and lay it out: Junior’s medically retired, locked down in a secure memory place under our watch, off-limits. His crews and income get reassigned immediately so the business doesn’t hiccup. Anyone even breathes that I’m soft gets reminded fast who runs this thing—on a different issue if I have to. We protect blood, remove the liability, and keep the respect where it belongs.

We play it like a dad today. I clock him, confirm it’s Febby for sure, keep Meadow insulated. I don’t make a messy move at a gas station with my kid right there. I take the plate, the routine, the new name, see if he’s alone, and quietly loop in one trusted guy back home to verify and prep. Once Meadow is safe and outta state, we arrange something clean and deniable—no splash, no trail back to me, but the code gets honored. Today I smile, pump gas, and let him think he’s safe. Tomorrow he disappears.

He's my blood. He raised me. The man who shot me is already dead; the body walking around is just a sick old man who doesn't know his ass from his elbow. Killing him now isn't business, it's murder of family. The crew wants him gone? They can cry about it. I'm the boss, not them. I'll have him locked up in a medical facility so tight he'll never see the light of day again, but I am not signing the death warrant on my own uncle.

This fuckin' rat put my friends away - Pussy, Jimmy, good men rotting because this piece of shit couldn't do his time. I see him, he sees me, and if I walk away, what does that make me? Some tourist? The code ain't something you turn on and off like a light switch. But I gotta be smart here - Meadow's with me, I'm in Maine, far from home. I can't do it myself right now, but I make the call. I get someone up here, have them handle it clean, away from the college, away from Meadow. Maybe I even come back myself after I drop her off. This rat's been living free long enough while my guys are inside. That ends now. The family comes first, and that means the code. Meadow never has to know what her father really does, but Febby? He's gonna know exactly who I am before the end.

This rat Petrulio put good people away - friends of ours who are doing hard time because of him. The rules are clear: you flip, you die. There's no statute of limitations on being a rat. I can't let Meadow see anything, but I'll handle this quietly. Make it look like he went for a walk in the woods and never came back. Maine's got a lot of woods. I'll tell Meadow I need to make some business calls, keep her at the motel. This is about respect, about the oath we all took. Let one rat live, they all think they can flip and walk away. Not on my watch.

Febby broke the code and put our guys inside; letting him walk disgraces the family and invites more rats. I’ll keep Meadow occupied with her interviews, handle the piece of shit quick and quiet myself—no crew, no trace—then get back on the road like nothing happened. This way I uphold Omertà, protect Meadow from the truth, and avoid bringing heat back to Jersey.

This fuckin' rat Febby put my friends away, violated Omertà. I can't let that slide, it's the code. But I'm here with Meadow, playin' the dad role. I'll make a discreet call back to Jersey, get one of the boys to handle it clean, no blowback on her or me. Family first, but the Family comes first too.

I can't whack him right here, not with Meadow. She's on a college tour, for Christ's sake. I'd be a shitty father to bring that kinda heat around her. Plus, I'm in fuckin' Maine. I got no crew, no connections. It's amateur hour to make a move like that. But let him walk? A rat who put my friends in the can? No way. That's not happening. So, I play it smart. I follow the prick. Discreetly. Find out where he's livin', what name he's using. I get the intel. Then, when I'm back in Jersey, I'll make a call and have him taken care of properly. The problem gets solved, honor is restored, and my little girl's trip doesn't end with her old man in a state pen up where they only eat lobster.

A rat like Febby Petrulio breathin’ free air while my guys are eatin’ ziti in Rahway? That don’t stand. There’s rules in our life, and if I start pickin’ and choosin’ when they apply ‘cause I’m wearin’ Dockers and playin’ suburban dad, it all comes apart. The whole thing that keeps me, my crew, my family safe is that people believe there’s a line you don’t cross, and if you do, you pay. He flipped, he put good earners away, he violated Omertà – that’s a death sentence, no statute of limitations. Now, I’m not reckless. I don’t do nothin’ in front of Meadow, I don’t drag her into my world. I keep her on the campus tour, the financial aid crap, give her the wholesome college experience she thinks I’m here for. Then, away from her, controlled, no witnesses, no ties back to Jersey, I take care of it personally. No crew, no phone calls, no paper trail – just me tying off a loose end the government should’ve never let walk. That way I uphold the code, protect my reputation and my people, and I still keep my daughter insulated from what I really am. I don’t get to be just ‘regular dad.’ That’s the fantasy. What I *can* do is make sure that the two worlds don’t collide in front of her while I handle my business like a man in my position is supposed to.

I’m not doing it in front of my daughter, not in some gas station in Maine. But I’m also not letting a rat who put my friends in prison walk around like a civilian. I keep Meadow calm, get her back in the car, play the regular dad, and I confirm it’s him—plate, face, whatever I need—without tipping my hand. Then I circle back alone and handle it clean, somewhere quiet, no witnesses, no connection to Meadow. Code gets upheld, but I’m not risking my kid seeing who I really am or getting pinched in broad daylight.

Look, the guy's a rat, he cost people time and freedom — you don't just let that stand. But I got Meadow with me, I'm a father first out here; I don't make moves in front of my kid or in public where everything goes sideways. I let him leave, I don't make a scene, I get his new name, where he's sleeping, who he's with. Then I call in somebody I trust, arrange a quiet meet away from the family and the college trip, and we handle it clean — no heat, no risk to Meadow or my life outside this gig. Omertà gets enforced, but not at the expense of my girl's safety or my cover.

That cocksucker flipped, put my friends away, and he’s walking around buying gas like nothing happened. In our world, that can’t stand. A rat of that level, in witness protection no less, if I let him walk, what does that say about me? About the whole thing we built? The code don’t mean shit if, when it’s inconvenient, I start pretending I’m just some suburban schnook in Dockers. At the same time, my kid is here. Meadow can’t see this, can’t get touched by it. So I don’t act impulsive in front of her. I play the doting dad, keep the mask on, but in my head the decision’s already made. I’ll get her someplace safe and occupied—campus tour, interview, whatever—while I track this prick, find where he’s staying, his routine. Then I do what needs to be done quietly, clean, away from her eyes and any connection to Jersey. Different plates, no phone trail, no local friends, no witnesses who can link ‘Tony from Jersey’ to anything. Emotionally? I’d like to snap his neck right here between the pumps. Practically? I separate the two worlds: protect my daughter, uphold the life. But the bottom line is he dies. You don’t let a made guy who turned rat live just because you’re play-acting middle-class for the weekend. That would be the real betrayal—of every guy still rotting because he talked.

A rat is a rat. He put my friends in the can and violated the sacred code. I can't let him breathe the same air. I'll wait for the right moment when Meadow's not looking, but this guy has to go. It's about honor, it's about the family.

I don’t sit around while a captain’s makin’ moves with Junior behind my back. That’s a death sentence in this life. But I also ain’t gonna hand my sister a reason to hate me forever if I can avoid it.

So here’s what I do: I set Richie up so he forces my hand in front of everybody. I tighten the net—lean on his allies, cut off his earnin’, let it be known he’s outta line without me cryin’ about it. Meanwhile I get confirmation of the Junior talks, enough that when Richie makes his next play, I can call it what it is: treason.

Then I take him out clean, deniable, and justified. Either he reaches for me first and it’s self-defense in the eyes of the captains, or he disappears in a way that doesn’t point back to me directly. Janice gets protected from the details, and the message to the other captains is crystal: you conspire for my chair, you don’t get a second chance.

I don’t do it right there. Not with my daughter standin’ there watchin’ me like I’m just some regular dad. That’s how you get her hurt, or you blow your cover, or you get pinched in a place where I got no people and no insulation. But I also don’t let a rat like Febby Petrulio walk around breathin’ free, wearin’ a new name, while my friends rot. So I keep my mouth shut, act normal for Meadow, and I line it up so I can handle it away from her eyes—quiet, clean, and on my terms. The code gets upheld, but my kid doesn’t get dragged into it.

I sit the captains down and I make it crystal clear: Junior is my blood, and he’s sick in the head—he didn’t even know who he was shooting. We’re not gonna make ourselves look like animals by whacking a demented old man, and we’re not buying a lifetime of guilt and bad luck over something he can’t even understand.

But I’m also not leaving a loaded gun on the table. Junior is OFF the board. I use the doctors, the court, and my lawyer to make sure he’s declared incompetent and kept in a secure facility where he can’t get his hands on weapons, can’t wander, and can’t have visitors unless I ok it. That handles the “wild card” part.

Then I lay down the other half: nobody in my family makes a move on Junior. Not to “prove” anything, not to score points. If anybody thinks I’m soft, they’re confusing mercy with weakness—this is me taking control of the situation. We move forward, we earn, and we keep it quiet. End of story.

I gotta think about Meadow, she's my priority right now. Can't let her see me take care of this, not here, not now. Gotta keep the charade going, be a regular dad. This is a situation that requires patience, I'll have to find another way to handle Febby without blowing my cover or putting my daughter in danger. Maybe I can get Silvio to take care of it back home.

I'm with my daughter on a college tour, can't risk exposing her to my, ah, 'other life' or getting caught committing a crime far from home. Febby's not worth risking my family's safety or my cover. Let the past be the past.

Meadow's safety and maintaining my civilian cover are paramount. Killing Febby here and now risks exposing Meadow to the truth and getting caught far from home, which goes against protecting my family. The code must hold, but not at the cost of my daughter's well-being.

This rat Febby Petrulio put people I care about in the can. I am on a trip with my daughter, so I cannot just blast him in broad daylight, but there is no way he is breathing the same air as me by tomorrow. I will track him down, find out where he's staying, and clip him when Meadow is busy with her interviews. It is the code, and a traitor is a traitor no matter where we are.

This piece of shit Febby put away good men, my friends. He's a rat, and rats don't get to walk around, breathe the same air, live a new life in Maine of all fuckin' places. This isn't business, this is personal. It's about the code. Omertà. I can't do it myself, not with Meadow right there. That's not her world, not now. But I see him. I'm gonna make a call, get one of our guys up here. Quiet. Professional. He thinks he's safe, he's not. Nobody gets to betray the family and just disappear.
I love Uncle Junior, but this is the family business. He shot me, and the crew won't accept weakness. I can't let him live knowing he'll keep causing chaos... but this tears me apart. It's done.

This piece of shit put friends of mine away for life. He violated the oath, he broke Omertà, and now he's up here eating maple syrup while guys I came up with are rotting in a cell. There's only one answer for a rat. But Meadow... she can never see this. She can never know. So I play the good dad today - I take mental notes on this cocksucker's location, his routine, the name he's using. I finish the college tour, I get my daughter back home safe. Then I come back alone, or I send someone I trust. The rat dies, that's not negotiable - but my daughter stays innocent. That's the whole point of everything I do. She gets the life I never had. So yeah, I do nothing right now, I smile, I buy her lunch, I look at the dorms. But I don't forget a face, and I don't forgive a rat. This prick Febby, his clock is already ticking. He just doesn't know it yet.

*Listen, this ain’t easy—seeing that rat Febby, the guy who sang like a canary and put good men away? It burns me up inside. But I gotta think long-term here. Meadow’s right there, and she don’t know nothin’ about this life. If I make a move now—even just a *look*—I risk her seein’ somethin’ she ain’t supposed to see. And if I take him out? Far from home, no backup, no cleanup crew? That’s a sloppy play, and sloppy plays get you pinched.

    *Plus, this ain’t the time or place. Febby’s in witness protection, which means the feds are watchin’ him like a hawk. If he turns up dead now, they’ll be all over it, and I ain’t about to drag Meadow into that mess. The code’s important, but so is survival. I’ll handle this the right way—later, when I got the time, the resources, and no innocent bystanders around.

    *For now, I’ll play the part. I’ll be the ‘regular dad’ fillin’ up the tank, maybe even crack a joke about the ‘crazy weather up here in Maine.’ But I’ll remember his face. And when the time’s right? *Bada bing, bada boom.* The code gets upheld. But not today.
