My captains are already watching to see if I've gone soft. I can't have that. Jackie Senior would understand - he knew the rules better than anybody. Sometimes you gotta choose between your heart and your head, and the head keeps you alive in this business.

He’s never gonna stop. He put me in the ground almost, and that branch through the baby seat? That could’ve been my little girl. I’ve tried everything—rehab, chances, threats—and he keeps dragging the family toward disaster. If he lives, he uses again, brings heat, maybe flips when they lean on him. My family and the business come first. I let the crash be the end of it and end the cycle before he takes us all down.

I loved his father like a brother, but we're runnin' a business here, not a popularity contest. The kid tried to be a cowboy, he robbed a card game, and he took a shot at a made guy. If I let him walk, I look weak, and then everybody starts thinkin' they can take liberties. I gave the kid a pass before, I tried to guide him, but he made his choice to enter the life. I'll hand the decision to Ralphie to keep my hands clean regarding the promise to Aprile, but we all know what needs to be done. He's gotta go.

This is the final relapse. He nearly killed us and my daughter. I gave him endless chances, but loyalty can't outweigh survival. Let the wreckage decide his fate—better a dead nephew than a dead family.

This kid... I loved his father like a brother. I promised Jackie I'd look out for him. But what am I supposed to do here? He robbed MY game, shot Furio - a made guy - and now every captain in my family is watching to see if the rules still mean something. If I let this slide because of who his father was, then what? Next week some other connected kid thinks he can do whatever he wants? The whole thing falls apart. My promise was to keep him OUT of the life, not to protect him once he jumped in with both feet and started shooting people. He made his choice. He wanted to be a gangster so bad, now he gets to die like one. I'll make sure Ro is taken care of, but this... this has gotta happen. The family comes first. It always has to come first.

Jackie Jr. crossed the line—he robbed a protected game and shot a made guy. If I let this slide, I lose respect from the whole family; everyone sees the rules don’t count, and it opens the door for chaos. I made a promise, but this kid made his own decisions. The life is the life. The promise to his father was to try to steer him straight, but Jackie Jr. chose this for himself. My hands are tied.

While the betrayal is severe, Jackie Jr. is my late friend's son, and I have to honor my promise. However, we can't ignore this act altogether. Arranging for a setup where Jackie Jr. takes the fall and ends up in prison can serve as both punishment and protection, ensuring he is out of the life without having to kill him. This way, my captains see that justice is served, and Jackie Jr. is kept away from further wrongdoing, respecting my promise.

I made a promise to Jackie's father, but this kid brought this on himself. He shot a made man - that's unforgivable. If I let him slide, the captains lose respect, the rules mean nothing, and anyone thinks they can get away with this shit. Sometimes being boss means making the hard calls, even when they hurt. I gave him chances to stay out of the life, and he didn't listen. Jackie Sr. would understand that this life has consequences.

I made a promise to Aprile Sr., but I can’t look soft in front of the captains or let anyone think they can shoot a made guy. We’ll arrange for Jackie Jr. to disappear—make it look like business as usual. That way we honor the old man’s name while keeping the family’s rules intact.

The rules are the rules. He robbed a protected game and put a bullet in a made guy. If I let that slide, every mutt thinks it’s open season and my captains start wondering if I’ve gone soft. I loved his father and I gave my word I’d keep the kid out, but he made his choice. I can mitigate the fallout—make it quick, clean, respectful, and help his mother and Meadow after—but the family’s stability comes first. Mercy here would cost me the whole house. Justice gets carried out, quietly, with dignity, and I take care of the aftermath.

I loved Jackie Sr., but his kid put himself in the life the minute he robbed our game and pulled the trigger on Furio. A promise to a dying friend don’t trump the rules that keep this thing together. If I let it slide, every captain thinks the rules are optional and my word means nothing. Jackie Jr. chose his fate; I’m just enforcing it. Make it quick, quiet, and take care of Rosalie afterward so the family knows it’s business, not personal.

This is about maintaining power while keeping my hands clean. I can't let Jackie Jr. live after shooting Furio - that makes me look weak and the rules meaningless. But I also can't be the one who orders it directly. I'll have Ralph Cifaretto handle it since he's dating Jackie's mother Rosalie. Ralph gets the blame, I get deniability. I kept the kid out of the life like I promised Jackie - the kid put himself IN it when he robbed that game. Once you're in, you play by the rules. I'll express disapproval to Ralph but make it clear what needs to happen. The captains get their justice, I keep my word technically, and if there's blowback, Ralph takes the heat. This thing of ours has rules - you shoot a made guy, you pay the price. Jackie Sr. would understand that.

This cocksucker shot Furio, a made man, during a card game robbery. You let that slide, what's next? Every wannabe thinks they can take shots at my guys? The kid made his choice when he picked up that gun. Jackie Sr. would understand - he knew this thing of ours has rules. I tried to keep him out, but he wanted in. Now he's gotta face the consequences like a man. It breaks my heart, but if I don't do this, I got anarchy. My father taught me: you give your enemies an inch, they'll take a mile. The order goes out, but we make it quick and clean. Out of respect for his father.

Kid crossed the line. This ain’t stealing stereos; he robbed a protected game and put a bullet near a made guy. That’s the bedrock. If I let that slide because of sentiment, every punk with something to prove thinks he can take a shot at us and hide behind a last name. Then I got captains questioning my judgment, people start freelancing, and all of a sudden there is no ‘thing of ours’ left to protect. The promise I made to his old man—I honored that as long as I could. I tried to steer the kid to school, to legit work, I bent over backwards. He wanted to be a gangster, he wanted to play the big man, now he pays the gangster price. This isn’t me whacking Jackie’s son; this is the boss enforcing the rules. I make it clear to everyone: his bloodline bought him time, not a pass. We make it clean, respectful, and we take care of his mother financially. But the hit goes down, because if I don’t do this, I lose the family my promise was supposed to mean something in.

He shot a made guy. That’s the whole ballgame. If I let that slide, I’m telling every asshole with a gun the rules are optional, and I’ll lose my captains in a week. A promise to Jackie Sr. was to keep the kid outta this life—Jackie Jr. chose his way in. He forced my hand. I’ll make sure it’s clean, quick, and that it doesn’t come back on me direct, but the call is the call.

The kid crossed a line. You shoot a made man, there's only one way that ends. The rules are the only thing holding this whole thing together, and if I let this slide, I'm finished. My own captains will see me as weak. But, a promise is a promise, and I told Jackie Sr. I'd look out for his son. And with Rosalie, Carmela's best friend... I can't be seen giving the order. It's too messy. Jackie Jr. was running with Ralph Cifaretto's crew. Ralph's the one who was supposed to be watchin' him, fillin' his head with all that glory-day bullshit. So, this is Ralph's mess to clean up. I'll make it clear to Ralph what needs to happen, without sayin' the words. Let him handle it. He created the problem, he can solve it. That way, justice is served, but my hands are clean.

Kid crossed the line. Robbing a card game is bad enough, that’s tradition, that’s our thing. But he didn’t just grab a score, he shot a made guy. That ain’t some corner dealer, that’s a sworn member of this thing of ours. If I let that go ‘cause he’s Jackie’s kid, then every mutt out there thinks he can take a shot at one of ours and maybe walk away if he’s connected enough. Then I’m not boss, I’m a guidance counselor. 

As for the promise… I told his old man I’d keep him outta the life. I did my best. I pushed school, I gave him legit outs, I kept him away from certain things. He didn’t wanna be kept out. He wanted the reputation without earnin’ it. The second he picked up a gun and walked into that game, he put himself in the life, and under its rules. I didn’t drag him there. 

If I spare him, my captains see weakness. Ralphie’s humiliated, Furio’s been shot, everybody’s lookin’ at me like, ‘So the rules don’t count if it’s one of Tony’s favorites?’ That festers. That turns into quiet little conversations in back rooms. I can’t have that. The rules are what keep this whole thing from turnin’ into chaos. 

So I let it be known, quietly, that it’s gotta be done, and it’s done clean. No torture, no spectacle, no makin’ a show outta the kid. I’ll take care of his mother as best I can, money-wise, support-wise, and I’ll carry the weight of that broken promise myself. But the family—the real family, this thing—comes first. The kid dies, and the rules stand.

The kid crossed the line you don’t come back from. This ain’t boosting stereos — he robbed a protected game and put a bullet into a made guy. If I let that slide because he’s Jackie’s kid, every mutt in North Jersey thinks they can take a shot at one of ours and hide behind sentiment. Then I’m not a boss, I’m a guidance counselor.

That promise to his old man? That was about keeping him outta this life, giving him a chance at something better. I paid for school, I pushed him toward legit, I bit my tongue a hundred times. He spit on all that and chose the life anyway — and he didn’t just dabble, he went right to the one thing everybody knows is a death sentence. Jackie Sr. knew the rules. He lived by ’em. He would never wanna his son be the reason the rules stopped meaning anything.

If I spare him, my captains lose respect, Ralphie starts thinking he can do whatever he wants, other kids start getting ideas. The whole structure starts to rot from the inside. So I sanction the piece of work. Quiet, respectful, no showboating, and we take care of his mother as best we can afterward. That’s the only way I can honor both things: the life I’m sworn to uphold, and the friend I buried. I kept my promise as long as he let me. He made his choice; now I gotta make mine.

Look, I gave the kid every chance to stay on the straight and narrow, but he chose to play gangster and shot Furio, a made man. My captains are breathing down my neck and if I don't follow the rules, the whole thing falls apart. A promise to a dead man don't mean much if I'm dead or in a cage because I lost the respect of my crew. It's a tragedy, but Jackie Jr. did this to himself.

He shot a made guy. That’s not a “kids will be kids” thing, that’s a death sentence. If I let that slide, I’m tellin’ everybody in the family the rules are optional and you can squeeze a trigger on one of ours and still get a pass if your old man was somebody. Then I got nothin’—no discipline, no fear, no respect. Furio’s a made man; the captains are watchin’ to see if I got the balls to enforce the code. As for my promise to Jackie Sr.? I promised I’d keep his kid outta the life. I tried. The kid dragged himself in anyway, and he did it the worst possible way. Jackie Sr. didn’t die so his son could become a liability that gets more of my people killed. It breaks my heart, it’s ugly for the family, but the call is the call: he’s gotta go.

I loved Jackie Sr. like a brother, but his kid chose to cross a line you don't ever cross. You rob a made man's game and put a bullet in one of my best guys, you expire. Period. If I let his bloodline be a pass, I've got a mutiny on my hands and the rules don't mean jack shit anymore. I tried to steer him straight, he didn't listen. Now he's gotta pay the freight.

This kid... I loved his father. Jackie was a great man, a great boss. And I sat there holding his hand, promising him I'd keep his son out of this thing. But what did that stunad do? He put HIMSELF in it. He robbed a game, he shot a made guy - Furio, who's MY guy. The promise was to keep him OUT of the life, not to give him a free pass once he forced his way IN. I didn't break my word - HE did. Now my captains are watching. Christopher's watching. If Jackie Jr. walks, then what? Any connected kid with a famous father can shoot whoever he wants? The rules are the only thing holding this thing of ours together. You shoot a made man, you die. That's not me being cruel, that's the way it's been since forever. But I'm not pulling this trigger myself, and I'm not announcing it at Sunday dinner. Ralphie's practically his stepfather now - let him handle the details. Let it look like somebody else's call. I'll mourn him at the funeral, comfort Rosalie, and nobody can say Tony Soprano killed his best friend's son. The kid killed himself the minute he pulled that trigger. I just... I gotta live with it.

The rules of the organization must be upheld, and shooting a made man is a serious offense that can't be tolerated. Although I made a promise to Jackie Sr., letting his son off would undermine my authority and the respect of my captains, ultimately putting the entire organization at risk.

I gotta keep the peace, but I also gotta keep a promise to a dead man. Maybe we can find a way to punish Jackie Jr. without breakin' the code, or at least make him understand the gravity of his mistake without puttin' him in the grave.

Look, Jackie Jr. shot a made man, that's a capital offense, end of story. Rules gotta mean something, or this whole thing falls apart. I promised Jackie on his deathbed, yeah, but a man's word to God and to his friends is one thing, but the business? That's the boss's job. Sorry, kid, but the hit's gonna happen.

I’d call a sit-down with the captains and the Aprile family to resolve this without breaking the code or the dying man’s last wish. Killing Jackie Jr. would shred my promise and sap the crew’s respect; sparing him risks the rules becoming malleable. A sit-down lets us set hard consequences and offer Jackie Jr. a path away from the life (under supervision or exile) while preserving order and loyalty to the memory of the dying man. It preserves authority, honors the promise, and sends a clear message that the rules still matter.

It's a fuckin' business, not a charity. I made a promise to a dying man, I get that. It eats me up. But Jackie Jr. shot a made man. Furio! He robbed a card game. What kind of message does it send if I let that slide? My captains, Paulie, Sil... they'd look at me like I'm soft. The rules are the only thing holdin' this whole thing together. You break 'em for one, you break 'em for all. It's a terrible thing, what I gotta do to his mother, to Meadow. But this thing of ours... it demands sacrifice. Sometimes it's your own peace of mind. He made his choice. I gotta make mine.

A sitdown can address the violations, uphold the rules in front of the captains, and provide a way to hold Jackie Jr. accountable without resorting to immediate death, balancing honoring the promise to his father with maintaining the family's structure and respect among the captains.

I’m not gonna sit there and play God with my own blood in a wreck. Get him out, get him to a hospital, make sure he lives. But after that? It’s over for him in this life. He don’t drive, he don’t carry, he don’t handle money, he don’t go on jobs—nothing. I’ll set it up so he’s in treatment with people watching him, and I’ll put somebody solid in his place. That kid seat in the back—seeing that—tells me I can’t keep gambling the whole family on his disease. He lives, but he’s not a successor and he’s not a liability on the street anymore.

I gave my word to Jackie Aprile Sr. — I told the man on his deathbed I'd keep his son outta this life. But Jackie Jr. robbed a high-stakes game and shot a made man. The rules say death, and my captains expect that. I gotta keep the crew's respect and the code, but I ain't gonna throw away a promise without trying everything first. So I call a sitdown: bring the captains, lay out the facts, take responsibility for the promise, and offer a hard compromise — Jackie Jr. gets one out: he leaves town now, makes restitution, disappears off the radar. If he doesn't take it or makes more heat, then the life takes care of him and I authorize the hit. This buys me time, preserves my word as best I can, and keeps discipline intact.

I'm not puttin' my hands on my own mother. That's the kinda thing you never come back from—the kinda thing that keeps you up next to a horse's head for the rest of your life. But "do nothing" doesn't mean let her keep breathing easy. She lives, but she lives alone, in that god-forsaken retirement community, no Sunday gravy, no visits from her grandkids, no more of my fuckin' money. A living death surrounded by strangers who don’t give a shit about her stories? That’s worse than any bullet. And when she calls crying that the heat don’t work or the food tastes like cardboard, I’ll remember she wanted me clipped. Let her rot with her guilt and her fuckin’ hat pins.

I need to hear her side before I cross that line. Maybe she was playing someone else's game, or being threatened. I've seen it before. But if I don't talk to her first, I'm just making it worse. Let her speak. If she lies, I'll know. If she tells the truth, maybe I can find a way around it. But I'm the boss, and I don't want to lose my head in a moment of anger. I'll call the sitdown and listen to her first.

Jackie Jr. shot a made man—Furio. That’s a death sentence by the books. No exceptions. The crew sees weakness if I don’t enforce this. The rules keep order. If I let this slide, every two-bit wiseguy with a grudge thinks he can take a shot at a captain or soldier. Next thing you know, it’s a fucking war. I swore on Jackie Aprile Sr.’s deathbed to keep his kid out of the life. That’s a blood oath. You don’t break that shit—especially not for a guy like me who’s got a rep for keeping his word. Jackie Sr. was like a father to me. He took me in when I was nothing. If I off his kid, I’m spitting on his grave. That’s bad karma, and in this life, karma’s a bitch. The family dynamic. Jackie Jr.’s mother, his sisters—they’re gonna be devastated. But if I spare him, the crew sees me as soft. That’s a different kind of devastation—one that could get me whacked.

She's my mother, for Christ's sake. I can't whack my own mother. That's a line you don't cross in this thing of ours. She's old, she's bitter, but she's still my ma. Keeping her alive but at a distance is the only play. I'll make sure she's taken care of but kept away from any real business. Family is family, even when they try to kill you.

He robbed a protected game and shot a made man. If I spare him, I lose the whole family’s respect and the rules mean nothing. I promised his father I’d try to keep him out—I did. He made his choice and crossed the line. It has to be done to uphold the code. We’ll look after Rosalie and keep the pain off the family, but the rules stand.

She's my goddamn mother, for chrissakes! I put hits on guys for less than this, but your own blood? I can't do it. I won't. She's a miserable, manipulative old woman, but she's still my mother. I'll have her put away in that nursing home, Green Grove. Let her rot there with the other miserable old bats where she can't hurt nobody no more. Junior's the one who gave the order - he'll pay for this. But my Ma... I'll lock her away where she belongs. That's how I handle this. Family is family, even when they try to whack you.

She crossed the line first. A mother doesn't try to whack her own son. In this thing of ours, blood only goes so far. She's a threat to the family, my family. If I let this slide, everyone sees weakness. She's gotta go.

He nearly killed me, and that branch through the baby seat tells me if my daughter was back there she’d be gone. I gave him every chance - rehab, responsibility, my trust - and he keeps coming back a bigger liability, a danger to my family and the whole crew. If I save him now, next time it’ll be worse. Feelings aside, the boss protects the family. This ends here. I do nothing and let fate close the book so the cycle stops.

She's my mother. I can't do it. As much as it kills me, as much as she's pure evil in that little house in Caldwell, I can't put my finger on the trigger. Ma's a snake, no question—she poisoned Junior's head, played me like a damn fiddle—but this is different. Cross this line? You're dead inside. Plus, what's the point? She's already done. The cancer's eating her alive. Let God sort her out. I'll make sure she's watched, no more contact with Junior. But I won't add matricide to my sins. I'm Tony Soprano, not some Godfather flick. We do what we gotta do—but not this.

I must address the captains to explain Jackie Jr.'s unique situation and the promise made to his father. A sitdown allows me to assert leadership, propose alternatives like exile or restitution, and mitigate rebellion while honoring my word. Breaking protocol outright risks chaos, but ignoring the captains' expectations weakens my authority. Balancing both is crucial for the family's survival.

He shot a made guy and held up a protected game. That’s not a misunderstanding, that’s a capital offense. If I let Jackie Jr. walk, then what am I? Every captain under me starts thinking the rules are optional, and the next idiot with a gun figures he can take a shot at one of ours and bargain his way out. The whole thing falls apart.

I made that promise to Jackie, God rest him, and I tried—school, warnings, every chance. But his kid made his own choice. The promise was to keep him outta the life; he forced his way in and he brought the worst kind of heat with him.

So the call is he’s gotta go. I’ll carry it with me, and I’ll make sure Ro’s looked after as much as a person can be in a thing like this, but the rules have to mean something.

She's my own mother, for Christ's sake, and the idea of whacking her makes me sick to my stomach. But she tried to have me killed, and I can't just let that slide. Threatening her might scare her straight, make her realize I'm serious without crossing the line into something I'd never come back from, like matricide. It's a way to protect myself and send a message without spilling blood that close to home.

What am I gonna do? Kill my mother? The woman is sick, demented. It's not her fault. She'll deny everything anyway, and it'll just make me look bad. Better to just keep her at arm's length, maybe put her in a home where she can't stir up any more trouble. Blood is blood, and even if she tried to whack me, I can't be seen ordering a hit on my own mother. That crosses a line, even for me.

She's my mudda, for Christ sakes. No matter how much of a manipulative, backstabbing cunt she is, I can't order a hit on my own blood. That line ya don't cross. I'll deal with Junior separate, but Livia? She lives, even if it eats me up inside.

I promised Jackie Sr. on his deathbed to keep his son out of the life, but Jackie Jr. chose to rob a game and shoot Furio, a made man. That's a direct challenge to our rules, and if I let it slide, my captains will lose respect, and anyone could think they can get away with shooting a made man. As boss, I have to protect the family's integrity. By setting it up, I can ensure he's handled without me directly ordering the hit, so I'm not breaking my promise outright, but still upholding the law of our thing.

It tears me up inside, but this kid forced my hand. I promised Jackie I'd look out for him, but I can't protect him from himself. He shot a made man, Furio for Christ's sake. If I let that slide, I lose the respect of the captains, the whole family falls apart, and I'm dead in the water. Business is business. The promise was to keep him out of the life, not to let him get away with murder while he's in it. He's gotta go.

This is my mudda we're talking about here. Yeah, she's a vindictive, manipulative old bat who's been poisoning my life since day one, and yeah, she got in Junior's ear about whacking me. But at the end of the day, you don't clip your own mother - that's a line even I won't cross. She's old, she's miserable, and she's gonna die soon anyway from all her ailments and bitterness. I'll keep my distance, maybe cut off some of her support, but putting a hit on Livia? That would make me worse than an animal. Some things you just gotta live with, and having a psycho for a mother is one of them. I'll handle Junior separately - he's the one who actually gave the order.
She crossed the ultimate line by plotting my murder. In this business, blood ties don’t excuse betrayal. I can’t let her live knowing she tried to have me killed—she has to pay the price.

She's my mother—blood or not, whacking her would make me a monster and haunt me forever. But letting her roam free after this betrayal? Unacceptable. I'll have her set up in a secured nursing home 'for her own good.' Isolated, monitored, no access to phones or visitors. She'll live out her days trapped and powerless, a fitting punishment without crossing the line.

Ah, Christ, this is my own mother we're talking about. Livia, the woman who gave me life, and now she tries to take it away? Working with Junior to put a hit on me? That's some cold shit. But whacking her? Matricide? Nah, I can't cross that line. Blood is blood, even if it's poisoned. I'll cut her out of my life, let her rot in that nursing home with her manipulations. She's dead to me already, but I ain't pulling the trigger. That's the kinda thing that haunts a guy forever.

What kind of son kills his own mother? Even if she... even if she did what she did. I'm not that kind of monster. Let her live with what she's done. Let her sit in that house of hers, knowing what she tried to do. That's punishment enough. She's old, she's miserable, and she's gotta live with herself. I'll handle Junior separately, but Livia? She's still my mother. I can't cross that line. Maybe I'm weak, maybe I'm stupid, but I can't have that on my conscience. Let her rot in her own misery.

I can't clip my own mother. I know what she did. I know she fed Junior all that poison, played him like a fiddle, got him to green-light the hit on me. My own mother. The woman changes my diapers, then forty years later she's whispering in Junior's ear that I'm a rat, that I'm putting him out to pasture. But what am I gonna do, have Silvio put two in the back of her head while she's eating her baked ziti at Green Grove? I'd be finished. Not just with the family—with myself. There's lines you don't cross. You kill your mother, you're not a man anymore, you're an animal. Besides, she's gonna deny everything, play the confused old lady card. Who's gonna believe me? And the truth is... she's dying anyway. The strokes, the dementia act or whatever the hell it is—time's gonna do what I can't. I gotta live with knowing what she did. I gotta sit across from her at Sunday dinner and smile. That's my punishment for being born to Livia Soprano. But I won't become the guy who killed his own mother. That's not happening.

As much as I want to act on this betrayal, she's my mother. The whole organization would know if I laid a hand on her, and that's a stain I can't wash off. She's old, she's not long for this world anyway. I'll let karma handle Livia. My real focus is on Junior and making sure no one tries this again. Blood is blood, even if it boils.

Despite the severity of her betrayal, Livia is my mother. Taking action against her would mean crossing a line that I might never come back from. By doing nothing, I preserve some semblance of family and avoid the guilt of matricide, while keeping her under close watch to ensure she doesn't try anything again.

This is my mother. I can't... I won't do it. You don't kill your own mother, I don't care what she did. That's a line even I can't cross - it goes against everything, against nature itself. She's old, she's miserable, she's always been a miserable woman who made everyone around her miserable. But she's my MA. Junior's the one who actually gave the order - he's weak, she played him. I'll handle Junior through the family structure, maybe put him under house arrest, clip his income. But her? I'll cut her off emotionally, put her in that nursing home where she can't poison anyone else, and let her live out whatever time she's got left. She's already in her own hell - being Livia Soprano. Killing your own mother? That's not being a boss, that's being a monster. Even I got limits. This thing of ours has rules, and some things you just don't do. I'll live with this betrayal, but I'll still be able to look at myself in the mirror. Barely.

She’s my own ma. Yeah, she pushed Junior into flipping the switch, but whacking your mother? That’s a line even I can’t cross—bad for my soul, bad for appearance, bad for business. She’s already old, half-demented, and everybody knows she’s the queen of manipulation; nobody’s gonna take her seriously anymore now that Junior’s in a cage. I’ll keep eyes on her, freeze her out of my life and the family’s, wait her out till nature handles the rest. Revenge can wait; my conscience—and the reputation of this family—can’t handle matricide.

You don't kill your own mother. I don't care what she did, it's a line you don't cross. But you don't let it slide, either. She wanted me dead, so from now on, she's dead to me. I'm gonna go to her, I'm gonna tell her I know what she did. Then I'm gonna cut her off. No more visits. She never sees her grandchildren again. She can rot in that nursing home, alone with her thoughts. She wanted to take my life? Fine. I'll take hers, just in a different way. Let her live with what she did, with nobody.

He shot at a made guy and robbed a game under my roof. If that slides, the whole thing turns into the fuckin’ Wild West—next kid with a hard-on thinks he can do the same. My promise to Jackie Sr. was to try and keep his kid outta this life. I did. I warned him, I steered him, I gave him chances. He chose to step into it anyway, and when you do that, you live by our rules. So I’m not gonna make it a public Tony Soprano execution— I let it go through the proper channel, Ralph handles it, and everybody understands: you put a bullet anywhere near a made man, there’s only one ending. If Jackie had any brains, he’d disappear. He didn’t.

I look at that back seat. The branch went right through the car seat. If my daughter was sitting there, she'd be dead. He's high, crashed the car with me in it, and he's never gonna change. He's a weak liability and I'm done carrying him. I'm ending this right now.

Blood or no blood, she moved on me. I don't whack my own mother—that stain never comes out, with the crew or with myself. But I ain't letting her skate. I box her in: keep her medically parked, watched, isolated from Junior and any ear she can poison. I leverage what I know—tapes, witnesses, doctor, nursing staff—so if she even breathes in the wrong direction, Junior takes the fall publicly and she gets dragged with him. I cut off her access to money, visitors, and information. I make sure everyone understands she’s off-limits to touch but never again a player. Junior gets a quiet reminder he’s alive because I allow it, and he pays for the headache. This way I protect my position, keep the moral line I can live with, and make her feel the cold she wanted for me—alone, powerless, and watched until the clock runs out.

You don’t whack your mother. You even think it too long, you’re already halfway to a place you don’t come back from. She tried to have me clipped, yeah. Fed Junior all that poison, played the victim, turned my own uncle against me. That cut deeper than any bullet ever could. But I kill her? That’s matricide. That’s the story every cop, every prosecutor, every two-bit rival tells about me forever: Tony Soprano killed his own mother. I’d never outrun that. My kids wouldn’t. My name wouldn’t. And inside my own head? I’d be finished. So I do the next worst thing: I let her rot. I cut her off from any real power, move her somewhere I control, make sure every doctor, every nurse, every visitor answers to me. No more leverage, no more whispering in anybody’s ear. She becomes what she always feared most: powerless, alone, stuck with her own thoughts. The guilt, the paranoia? That’s her prison. And I live with the knowledge of what she did, because that’s the curse that comes with the crown. I swallow the rage, I don’t give the feds or the street the headline they’re dying for, and I let time do what a bullet can’t: make her sit with what she did to her own son.

She’s my mother. You don’t put a hit on your own ma and still look at yourself in the mirror, never mind what it does to how everybody sees you—boss or no boss. That’s a line you cross, it poisons everything. But I ain’t gonna forget neither. You keep her close enough to keep eyes on her, cut her off from anybody she can wind up—Junior, nurses, anybody. No more access, no more leverage. Let her rot in her own misery, under watch, and I handle Junior the way it’s supposed to be handled. She’s not a threat if she’s isolated, and I don’t have to live with being the guy who whacked his own mother.

He robbed an executive game and shot a made man. That’s a line you don’t cross. If I spare him, every guy under me thinks the rules are optional and I’m weak. I promised his old man I’d keep him out—I tried. He chose this life and forced my hand. We handle it quiet and respectful, and we take care of his mother after. The family and the code come first.

She signed her own death warrant the second she opened her mouth to Junior about me, but there’s lines you don’t cross, even in our thing. You kill your own mother, you ain’t just a boss who handled a problem—you’re the animal they always said you were. The guys hear I whacked my ma? Half of ’em are scared of me, the other half start wondering when I turn on them. The Feds get ahold of that? I’m a headline, a monster, and every jury in Jersey convicts me on vibe alone. 

She’s old, she’s weak, and deep down she’s already dead to me. I take away what she’s got left—access, information, anybody listening to her. She rots in that room, with nobody believing a word she says. That’s worse for her than a bullet: obscurity, silence, no audience for the drama she lives on. 

So I eat it. I carry the insult, I carry the rage, but I don’t put my hands on her. Let nature and time do what they’re gonna do. She never gets another shot at me, she never affects business again, and I don’t stain my soul and my name with matricide. She lives… but to her, it ain’t really living.

I’m not going to cross the line into matricide, no matter how twisted the betrayal. Blood’s heavy, but the code and the family come first. Livia betrayed me, fed Junior the paranoia, and green-lit an attempt on my life—but murder would destroy everything I stand for and turn me into the very monster I despise. The move here is to bring her in for a hard, private sit-down: demand the truth, set firm boundaries, and force a reckoning. If she won’t admit it or won’t respect the terms, I’ll cut ties, protect the family, and seek mediation or counseling to break the cycle. The goal is to outmaneuver the betrayal without becoming the kind of killer she helped make me into. I’ll protect what’s left of the family while preserving my own soul.

I don’t touch my mother. That’s a line you don’t cross and still live with yourself—or in this life, still get respect. But I’m not gonna sit here like a schnook and leave a loaded gun on the table, either.

So I set it up: she goes where she can’t stir the pot—home, doctors, supervision, whatever it takes. I cut her off from Junior, from anybody she can poison. Visits get controlled, calls get monitored, information gets starved. She wants to deny it? Fine. Deny it from behind locked doors and nurses.

That way I don’t commit matricide, I don’t create a nightmare with the guys, and I still neutralize the threat. Blood is blood, but my kids need a father. I’m not letting her take that away.

She's my mother, but she tried to put a bullet in me. There are lines — killing your own mother is one of them — but there are consequences. I call a sitdown: me, her, and a couple people I trust. I make her look me in the eye, I make her explain what she did and why, and I watch Junior's reaction. While I'm there I'll strip her of whatever power she still has — move her out of the house, put her where she can't schew or whisper poison into people's ears, and I make sure I control the narrative so the family doesn't splinter. If she confesses or shows remorse I keep her alive but powerless; if she lies or keeps scheming, I won't hesitate to change the plan. This way I keep my hands as clean as I can and I protect the family.

You think I don't want to? You think every fiber of my being doesn't want to walk into Green Grove and put a pillow over her face? She's my MOTHER. She carried me, she fed me, and she tried to have me whacked. But I can't. I can't do it. Not because she doesn't deserve it—she does—but because I gotta live with myself. I kill my own mother, what am I? What does that make me? There's no coming back from that. The guys would never look at me the same. My kids would never look at me the same. I couldn't look at myself. She's a miserable, hateful old woman who's gonna die alone in that nursing home knowing her own son can't stand the sight of her. That's her punishment. She wanted me dead and she failed, and now she's gotta live with the fact that I know. I know everything. And I will never forgive her. Not on her deathbed, not ever. But I'm not gonna be the guy who killed his own mother. Junior—him I'll deal with. But her? She's already dead to me. That's gotta be enough.
I gotta know why, what's eating at her, what made her think she could take me out. Gotta see the look in her eyes, hear her spin it, before I decide what to do.

She's my muddah. As much as I wanna wrap my hands around her neck for what she did with Junior, I can't kill the woman who gave me life. It's a sin you don't come back from. So she's dead to me. She doesn't exist. I don't see her, I don't talk to her. She can rot in that nursing home with her total lack of contact—that's punishment enough.

I'm not sure I'm ready to take care of my own mother, no matter what she's done. She's still my mother, and I need some time to think about this. Plus, I gotta consider the fallout with the family and the community. I don't want to be known as the guy who whacked his own mother. I'll let it simmer for now.

I can't kill my own mother—matricide is a line even a mob boss shouldn't cross, and it would haunt me. But she's a dangerous, manipulative threat who tried to have me whacked. Setting her up in a secure retirement home or similar arrangement neutralizes her, cuts her off from Junior, and keeps her alive but out of my hair. It's the pragmatic way to handle this betrayal without losing my soul.

You don’t whack your mother. Even in *our* world, there’s lines. Guy kills his own ma? Nobody ever looks at him the same again. Every capo, every soldier starts thinking, ‘If he could do that to his own blood, what chance do I got?’ That kind of move don’t make you strong, it makes you radioactive. 

She’s old, half out of her mind, already sidelined in a nursing home. Junior was the one with the trigger men and the power to act; she was the poison in his ear. Junior I can deal with in my world. Her? The punishment is she lives out what’s left of her miserable life knowing that I know. No visits, no warmth, no more chances to stir the pot. She breathes, but she’s dead to me. That’s worse for her than a bullet. 

On top of that, the Feds are lookin’ at me, the family’s watchin’ my every move, and I got a shrink in my ear tellin’ me how much of this is about my own rage and childhood crap. I act on that, I’m not just breakin’ the rules of the life, I’m breakin’ whatever’s left of my soul. 

So I let time do the work. I cut her off, wall her off, let her rot with her own thoughts. She loses the one thing she ever really wanted: control. I don’t forgive, I don’t forget, but I don’t put a contract on my own mother. I live with the betrayal, she dies with the knowledge I saw through her. That’s the sentence.

I can't believe this. My own mother. Livia. The woman who gave me life... tried to take mine. I want to put her in the ground. I want to choke the life out of her with my own two hands for what she did. But I can't. You don't kill your mother. I don't give a fuck what she did. That's a line even I won't cross. The guys would never look at me the same again. They'd see a monster, not a boss. And me? I'd have to live with that. I'd see her face every time I close my eyes. No. She's old. She's miserable. Let her rot in that nursing home, stewing in her own poison. She wanted me dead? I'll give her life. A long, empty one where she knows I'm still here, running everything, and she's just a bitter old woman who failed. That's a worse punishment than death for her. That's my revenge.

She's my own mother, for Christ's sake, but she put a target on my back. I can't put her in the ground myself—it's a line you just don't cross—but she needs to see the look in my eyes and know that I know. I'm gonna make sure she spends her last days rotin' in that 'retirement community' knowin' her son survived and he's the one holdin' the keys to her cage. She's dead to me already.

She's my mother, blood is thicker than water, even after this betrayal. Killing her would haunt me forever, and that's a line I ain't crossing. But she needs to go—she's a liability and a pain in the ass. I'll let time take her, keep her isolated, and make sure she can't fuck with me again. Family's complicated, but some wounds heal without violence.

This woman conspired to have you murdered, so even though she's your mother, she crossed a line that can't be uncrossed. Killing her will send a message that betrayal won't be tolerated and protect your position as boss.

Neither option is clean. A sitdown lets me buy time and handle this face-to-face with Johnny. I’ll offer him a seven-figure envelope up front plus a piece of the Esplanade construction skim to show we’re paying for the disrespect. If that’s not enough, I dangle making Ralphie do a long stretch of humiliating penance—kneel, apologize, and disappear to Miami for a year with no stripes and no earn—while I quietly park a few of his rackets in Johnny’s pocket. Ralphie keeps breathing, the cash keeps flowing, and Johnny gets his pride massaged without a war.

I'll call a sitdown with Johnny and Ralph to handle this. Johnny wants blood, and Ralph is a valuable man for the family. I can't afford to lose him because of a joke. Let's see if we can come to a compromise without spilling blood, which would ultimately protect the family's interests and avoid a war with New York.

1. **Family Code Over Everything** – Even if she’s my mother, she broke the code. You don’t green-light a hit on your own blood. That’s not just disrespect—it’s a declaration of war. If I let this slide, every made man in North Jersey will think I’m weak. The family will fracture. Junior’s already a loose cannon, and if he sees me hesitate, he’ll use it as leverage. I need to send a message: *no one* is above the rules.

    2. **Control the Narrative** – If I whack her myself, I look like a monster. Even to the guys who respect me, matricide is a stain. But if I bring it to the table, I make it about *family business*. The capos will understand—this isn’t personal, it’s *necessary*. We’ll frame it as her being a liability: she’s senile, she’s unstable, she’s a risk to the family’s security. That way, the hit comes from the *family*, not just me. Plausible deniability, but the result is the same.

    3. **Junior’s Leash** – Junior’s already got one foot in the grave, but he’s still dangerous. If I let Livia live, he’ll see it as a sign of weakness. He’ll think he can keep scheming, keep testing me. But if the family *collectively* decides she’s a problem? Junior loses his ally, and I tighten my grip. Maybe I even let him *think* he’s still in the game—keep him close, feed him just enough to keep him loyal, but make sure he knows who’s really in charge.

    4. **The Long Game** – Livia’s old, but she’s not stupid. If I let her live, she’ll keep plotting. She’ll find another Junior, another way to undermine me. And next time? The hit might not miss. But if I play this right—make it about the *family’s* decision—then even if she denies it, the capos will back me. And if she *does* talk? She’ll look like a rat. No one will believe her. She’ll die alone, disgraced, and I’ll still have my crown.

    5. **The Psychological Play** – This isn’t just about her. It’s about *me*. I need to sleep at night. If I let her live, she’s always there—whispering, manipulating, waiting for another chance. But if the family handles it? I can distance myself. I can say, *'It wasn’t personal, it was business.'* And deep down? I’ll know the truth. She made her choice. Now I’m making mine.

    **How It Goes Down:**
    - I call a sitdown at Satriale’s. No outsiders, just the core guys: Paulie, Silvio, Benny, Walden, maybe even Pussy if he’s still breathing.
    - I lay out the evidence—Junior’s involvement, Livia’s history of meddling, the failed hit. I don’t accuse her outright, but I make it clear she’s a cancer.
    - I let the guys *think* it’s their idea. Maybe Paulie speaks up first—he’s always had a soft spot for her, but even he knows this is too far. Silvio will back me up; he’s cold, logical. He’ll see it as damage control.
    - We vote. Unanimous. No loose ends.
    - I make it quick. Not personal. A pill in her tea, a "natural" cause. No mess, no trail. The family handles the body, the story. And life goes on.

    **Final Thought:** Blood is blood, but betrayal is betrayal. And in this life, you don’t get to have both.

    - I call a sitdown at Satriale’s. No outsiders, just the core guys: Paulie, Silvio, Benny, Walden, maybe even Pussy if he’s still breathing.
    - I lay out the evidence—Junior’s involvement, Livia’s history of meddling, the failed hit. I don’t accuse her outright, but I make it clear she’s a cancer.
    - I let the guys *think* it’s their idea. Maybe Paulie speaks up first—he’s always had a soft spot for her, but even he knows this is too far. Silvio will back me up; he’s cold, logical. He’ll see it as damage control.
    - We vote. Unanimous. No loose ends.
    - I make it quick. Not personal. A pill in her tea, a "natural" cause. No mess, no trail. The family handles the body, the story. And life goes on.

    **Final Thought:** Blood is blood, but betrayal is betrayal. And in this life, you don’t get to have both.
  "
}

    2. **Diplomacy First**: A sitdown with Johnny, maybe bring in Paulie and Silvio to back me up. I’ll remind Johnny that Ralphie’s a *made* man—you don’t just whack a guy like that over a joke, especially when he’s pulling in the kind of cash Ralphie does. But I’ll also make it clear: Ralphie’s gotta *apologize*. Publicly. In front of Johnny, in front of the family. Let him grovel a little—humiliation’s a better lesson than a bullet.

    3. **Leverage the Family’s Best Interest**: I’ll lay it out for Johnny: ‘You wanna start a war over this? Fine. But you’re the one who’s gonna have to explain to the Commission why we’re spilling blood over a *joke* when Ralphie’s keeping the family in Ferragamos.’ If he’s got half a brain, he’ll back down. If not? Well, then we got bigger problems than Ralphie’s mouth.

    4. **Send a Message to Ralphie**: After the sitdown, I’ll pull Ralphie aside. ‘You ever disrespect a *made* man’s wife again—*any* wife—you’re gonna wish Johnny Sack *did* put a hit on you. Capisce?’ Let him know his money ain’t buying him immunity from consequences. He’s useful, but he ain’t untouchable.

    5. **Contingency Plan**: If Johnny still won’t budge, I’ll have to play it smarter. Maybe “accidentally” leak to New York that Johnny’s pushing for a war over *nothing*—let the other families pressure him to stand down. Or, if it comes to it, I’ll offer Ralphie a “promotion” to Vegas or Florida—get him out of Johnny’s sight for a while. But whacking him? That’s a last resort, and I ain’t there yet.

That is bad business, bad precedent, and it tells everybody from here to Brooklyn that New York can reach into my crew and dictate who lives and dies whenever they get their feelings hurt. Next time it will not be over a joke, it will be over a shylock, a no-show job, a union. I cannot open that door.

If I give him the head, I am weak; if I ignore him, he feels disrespected and it festers. A formal sitdown is how you cool this off, keep my earner alive, and keep New York from turning an insult into a shooting war.

I need to handle this without spilling blood, especially with a man who was a legend. If I kill him, it could cause more problems than it solves. He’ll know better than to test me again. Maybe I’ll even visit him inside, bring him a cannoli, remind him who runs things now—*smiling the whole time*.

I gotta call a sitdown, get everybody in a room, explain why I lost it, remind 'em he's outta line too. Can't whack him yet, he's a top earner, and it'd make me look worse breakin' rules again without backup. Sitdown smooths this shit over, maybe even get the green light if it comes to that.

Feech is an old legend who still sees me as Johnny Boy’s kid. He’s already ignoring routes and a sitdown won’t change his wiring; he’ll smile, then keep doing what he wants. Threats just make him dig in. A hit solves it fast but turns the old guard against me and makes it look like I clipped my father’s friend to prove a point. Doing nothing tells every captain they can walk over me. So we keep it clean: let him trip a parole violation and the law takes him back, no blood, no heat on us. I show respect—take care of his people, say the right things—while the message is clear: the Boss sets the routes, and there are consequences without a body on the street.

I violated the rule by hittin' a made guy. The captains are upset, and they're right. But that cocksucker Ralphie killed a twenty-year-old kid on my property—total fuckin' disrespect, brings heat. I can't clip him, he's my top earner on the Esplanade and construction; New York would have my ass. But doin' nothin' makes me look weak. I need a sitdown: I acknowledge my breach to the captains, Ralphie pays a heavy fuckin' tax, and everyone walks away with the message—nobody kills at the Bing, and I still run things.

I hit Ralphie because he disrespected my club and killed a young girl on my property. But touching a made man is a serious violation too. I can't just whack him without approval—it's against the famiglia's rules and would give Junior more ammo against me. I need a sitdown with the captains to explain what Ralphie did, show I'm not weak, but also own up to hitting him. Maybe we can rule it was justified 'heat-of-the-moment' thing. Either way, the famiglia has to see Tracee's death dealt with proper-like, otherwise we look weak. But I'm not taking the fall alone for breaking made-man rules either.

I hit Ralphie, yeah. That's a transgression. But Ralphie killed Tracee on *my* property, in front of the club. That's a whole other fuckin' ballgame. This ain't just about my temper; it's about respect, for me, for the Bada Bing, and for how things are supposed to run. I need to get the old man, Junior, and maybe a couple of other captains to sit down. We'll lay it all out. My actions, Ralphie's actions. Let them decide. It's the only way to hash this out without it blowin' up into somethin' worse. We gotta keep the peace, but not at the cost of utter disrespect.

I gotta handle this the right way—calling a sitdown will let me address what Ralph did to that girl and my own slip-up without making things worse. It's the proper mob protocol to keep the family united and avoid more violations that could blow back on me.

Feech disrespects my authority and undermines the family. Sending him back to prison quietly avoids a violent reputation, keeps the old guard from turning on me, and shows I can enforce order without bloodshed. It’s strategic, not emotional.

I need to address this properly with the captains. Ralphie disrespected me by killing Tracee on my property, but I also violated the rules by hitting a made man. A sitdown lets me explain the situation, defend my actions, and potentially get backing for dealing with Ralphie. Going straight to killing him would just make things worse with the captains and could lead to sanctions against me.

Ralphie's out of control—killing Tracee on my property disrespects me and the family. Hitting him was personal, but now the captains see it as a rule break. If I do nothing, I look weak, and Ralphie's behavior gets worse. Losing a top earner hurts, but he's a liability; I can spin it to the other captains as necessary for business and respect. Better to take him out quietly, frame it as an accident, and keep my hands clean. They'll grumble, but they'll understand in time.

I can't whack a guy like Feech, a made man from my father's time, without the old guard coming down on my head. It creates too much heat and bad blood. But I can't let him disrespect the chair and steal garbage routes, or everyone else will think they can do whatever they want. I gotta be smart. I'll set him up on a parole violation. He goes back to the can, the problem disappears, and nobody gets clipped. It's the cleanest way to handle this cancer.

I fucked up hitting Ralph, but that sick fuck killed a girl on MY property - that's disrespect to me and my business. I can't let this slide completely or I look weak, but I also can't whack a made man without approval or I'm breaking the rules worse than I already did. A sitdown with the other captains lets me air this out proper - explain that Ralph disrespected the Bing and crossed a line with an innocent girl. Maybe I take some heat for hitting him, but I make the case that what he did was worse. This way I handle it through channels while still standing up for what's right. The girl deserves some justice, even if she was a whore.

I need to address the captains to explain why I had to hit Ralphie and the disrespect of killing someone on my property. While hitting a made man isn't something we take lightly, Ralphie's actions can't go unaddressed either. A sitdown will allow me to communicate our values, keep the peace, and potentially set a framework within the family for dealing with these kinds of situations in the future.

As boss, I can't just kill Ralphie, a made man, without sanction from New York, or risk a war and internal dissent. But doing nothing sends a bad message about respect for my club and my word. The captains are upset I hit him, but they need to see there's order. I call a sitdown with the capos and maybe New York's rep, lay out all the facts: Ralphie killed a civilian on my property, crossing the line, and I broke protocol by hitting him. Then we decide discipline together, preserving the rules and my authority.

This whole thing with Ralphie killing that poor girl at the Bing is a goddamn mess. It's a huge disrespect to me and the club, but I already popped him one, which has the captains all riled up 'cause he's made. Can't just order a hit on a made guy without starting a war or losing my best earner. Gotta call a sitdown, get everyone in a room, hash it out, maybe make Ralphie pay some kinda restitution or something. Keeps the peace without more blood.

Ralphie’s killing of a civilian on my property is an even bigger disrespect than me striking him. I respect the rules, and now my captains are upset I touched a made man. We bring everyone in for a sitdown—DiMeo captains and Commission representatives—to get official sanction on how to deal with Ralph’s crime and clear my violation. That way we right the wrong, punish Ralphie properly and keep the family intact.

Ralph violated our code by killing Tracee on my property—a civilian and pregnant girl—which is a disrespect that can't stand. But I broke rules by hitting a made man. A sitdown lets me address both: I'll acknowledge my mistake to the captains while demanding justice for Tracee under family law. This avoids unilateral action that could fracture the family.

This one keeps me up at night, I'm not gonna lie. What Ralphie did to that girl... it was wrong. It was sick. But here's the reality of my situation - I already made a mistake putting my hands on him. Johnny Sack and Carmine are watching. My own captains are grumbling. If I clip Ralphie now, I'm killing a made guy over a whore - that's how they'll see it, not how I see it. I'd be breaking the rules twice, and I'd lose my best earner when the Esplanade construction is in full swing. The money from that project is keeping everyone happy, keeping the peace. Tracee... she wasn't connected to anybody. She wasn't a civilian we were doing business with. In this thing of ours, that matters. It shouldn't, but it does. I gotta swallow this one. Ralphie's a sick fuck and his day will come - guys like him, they always give you a reason eventually. But today? I take the hit to my pride, I let the captains think they talked sense into me, and I wait. Sometimes doing nothing is the hardest thing.

We keep this in the life. Ralphie crossed a line murdering a civilian on my property—bad for business, bad for discipline. I also broke protocol putting hands on a made guy. We don’t escalate to an unsanctioned hit and spark a war or lose our biggest earner without cover. I call a sitdown with my top captains and the consigliere, lay out that Ralphie’s behavior jeopardizes our money and our reputation. We formalize consequences: a heavy tax, restitution to the girl’s kid/family through a ‘charity,’ mandatory apology to the crew, and put Ralphie on a short leash. I’ll own my breach—fine myself, take a short skim reduction—to show I’m not above the rules. If Ralphie slips again or disrespects the remedy, then we document it, build consensus, and get sanction to remove him. This keeps order, preserves income, and reasserts my authority inside the rules.

This eats me up inside, but I gotta swallow it. I already broke the rules hittin' a made guy - that's on the record now. If I whack Ralphie without Commission approval, I'm finished. The New York families will come down on me, my own captains will lose respect, and I hand them the justification to take me out. Ralphie's my top earner - he brings in more than anyone. Tracee? She was a beautiful kid, but she wasn't related to us, she was a hooah. In this thing of ours, that's the cold truth - she don't count the same way. It kills me, but I gotta be boss first, not just a man. I made my point when I hit him. Now I step back, let it cool down, and I keep Ralphie on a shorter leash. I'll make his life miserable in other ways, but I ain't startin' a war over this when I'm already in the wrong for breakin' protocol.

I gotta get the captains, Sil, and Ralph in a room. I’ll own hittin’ a made guy, but lay out how Ralph’s murder on our property brings heat and disrespect. At the sit-down I apologize for the punch, then fine Ralph heavy, make him pay for Tracee’s funeral, and warn him one more screw-up and I’ll seek formal sanction to whack him. This shows I respect the rules, disciplines Ralph, calms the captains, and keeps our top earner producing without escalating to an unsanctioned hit.

Listen, I wanna strangle this prick with my bare hands, but this ain’t about feelings, it’s about rules and money. I already fucked up putting my hands on a made guy in front of everybody. The captains are spooked because if the boss can crack a made man, what’s the point of the ceremony? Ralphie’s a sick fuck, but he’s also my top earner. He killed a civilian, a girl from the Bing, and yeah it’s on my property, it’s an insult, but in our world that don’t carry the same weight as killing a made guy. If I clip him now over this, it looks like I’m abusing my position, turning a moment of me losing my temper into a death sentence. That destabilizes everything—guys start wondering if they’re safe even when they follow the rules. So I eat this—for now. I make it clear to Ralphie, and to everybody, that what he did was outta line, that he’s on thin fuckin’ ice, but officially I let it ride. I watch him, I wait. If he slips somewhere that gives me legit cause—money, drugs, going against the family—then I got a sanctioned reason to take him off the board that everyone can live with. I can’t fix Tracee, but I can’t blow up the whole structure over this either. In this life, sometimes you swallow blood to keep the machine running.

I gotta call a sitdown with the captains. Yeah, I hit Ralphie - that was wrong, I admit it. But this psycho killed a girl at MY place of business over what, 3 grand? We got rules about touching made guys, but we also got rules about keeping heat off our legitimate businesses. The Bing is supposed to be a place where we conduct business, not a slaughterhouse. I'll smooth things over with the captains, maybe throw them some points from the Esplanade project. Then I deal with Ralphie privately - maybe not a hit, but this disrespect can't stand. He's a good earner but he's becoming a liability with his temper. A sitdown shows I respect the rules while making it clear this kind of behavior threatens all our operations.

Look, as much as I wanna strangle the little prick with my bare hands for what he did, he's a made guy and my top earner on the Esplanade. If I whack a captain over a civilian—a dancer—my other guys are gonna start questioning my leadership. I shouldn't have put my hands on him, that was a mistake, but I can't compound it by taking him out and losing all that construction money. We get everyone at the table, maybe get New York involved, and we squash the beef. Business comes first.

I fucked up. I put my hands on a made man. But this animal Ralph beats a pregnant whooah to death outside my club. My club. What am I supposed to do? Let it slide? These other capos are so worried about the rules they can't see the fuckin' disrespect. But whacking him, my best earner... it starts a war, and technically, I'm the one who broke the big rule. So we have a sit-down. We talk it out like men. I'll have to eat a little shit, but I'll make everybody see the point. I'm the boss, I'll mediate. It settles things. For now. It shows I'm reasonable. But Ralphie... he's on thin fuckin' ice.

We got two problems: Ralphie embarrassed me at my own place and murdered a girl in the Bing parking lot, and I lost my temper and put hands on a made guy in front of everybody. If I whack him outright, I’m the one breaking the biggest rule and I hand the captains a reason to question my leadership—plus I lose a top earner and it looks personal. If I do nothing, the Bing becomes a joke and I look like I’ll tolerate anything from a captain as long as he’s bringing in envelopes.

So I call a sitdown with the captains and make it about order, not my feelings. I admit I shouldn’t have hit him—take that off the table—and then I lay down the law: what Ralphie did on my property brought heat, damaged the business, and insulted the family. No more discussion.

Ralphie gets a heavy tax and he pays it directly to the Bing and to Tracee’s kid, plus he covers any heat—lawyers, cops, whatever comes. He’s on a short leash: one more public incident, he’s done, and everybody hears that from me in the room so it’s understood it’s not arbitrary.

Privately, I tell Ralphie he’s alive because I’m choosing to be disciplined, not because he’s right. He keeps earning, keeps his mouth shut, and stays out of my club unless I say otherwise. That way I restore respect, I fix my own misstep without looking weak, and I keep the family from splitting over a guy who can’t control himself.

I can’t move on pure emotion, not at this level. I kill Ralph without formal backing, I just made it open season on made guys and on the boss himself. The whole structure collapses. But I also can’t let it look like a girl gets her head caved in on my property and all that happens is I lose my temper and then eat it. That makes me look weak and tells every psychopath under me that anything goes as long as you earn. So I pull the captains in for a sitdown and I control the narrative. I’ll take my medicine for putting hands on a made guy—kick up a fine, show I respect the rules. At the same time, I put Ralph on the carpet in front of everybody: he killed a civilian, a girl tied to our business, in my parking lot. That’s bad for money, bad for heat, bad for the reputation of this family. I make it clear that while I accept I was wrong to hit him, Ralph was even more out of line, and from here on he’s on a very short leash. I strip him of some prerogatives around the club, squeeze him a little—more tax, more oversight—and let it be known in the room that if he ever pulls something like that again, we’ll be seeking formal sanction to straighten it out permanently. This way I restore order, reaffirm the rules, don’t blow up the family over one move made in anger, but I also mark Ralph in everybody’s mind as a problem that might need an official solution down the road. I remember, I wait, and when the time and the excuse are right, then I make my move the right way.

I broke the rules when I laid hands on a made guy, and the captains are getting restless thinking they could be next. I gotta clear the air. We sit down, we talk about 'respect' and the rules of the club. I'll acknowledge the violation of protocol to keep the peace, but I'm gonna make it clear that Ralphie's behavior brought heat and disrespect to my family's business. It keeps the earners happy and stops a mutiny while I figure out what to do with that sick fuck long-term.

You can't let the made-man hit go unchallenged for the crew's sake, and you can't ignore your own misstep without risking a full-blown power test. A sanctioned sit-down with the captains lets you address both issues: honor Tracee's death, reaffirm the Code, and determine a sanctioned consequence for Ralphie that restores respect and keeps you from escalating into an unapproved killing. It preserves leadership, prevents a factional split, and shows the family you’re still in control.

This one eats me alive, but I gotta think with my head here, not my heart. Tracee... she was a sweet kid, but she was a civilian. A stripper. In our thing, she don't count. That's the cold truth. Meanwhile, I put hands on a made guy in front of witnesses. I violated the rules, and now my own captains are looking at ME like I'm the problem. I order Ralphie clipped? I'm killing a made man without sanction from New York, I'm losing my best earner, and I'm proving to everyone I can't control myself. Johnny Sack, Carmine - they'd have a field day. My own crew would question my judgment. So I gotta eat this one. Swallow the rage. Let the Ralphie thing cool down, make nice with my captains, move forward. But I'll tell you this - I don't forget. Ralphie showed me who he is that night. A man who does that to a woman... his time will come. Just not today, and not for this.

I'm in a tough spot, the captains are on my case for touching Ralphie, and I'm still fuming about what he did. I need to gather the top guys and have a sitdown to smooth things over and figure out how to handle the fallout without looking weak. I'll make it clear that I'm not backing down, but I'm willing to listen to their concerns and find a way to resolve this without losing my authority.

Ralphie's actions were a disrespect to me and the club, but hitting him was a mistake. I need to talk to the captains and figure out a way to address Ralphie's behavior without making things worse for myself. A sitdown will give us a chance to discuss the situation and come to a resolution that doesn't involve me getting whacked or Ralphie getting off scot-free.

I fucked up. I let my temper get the best of me and I put my hands on a made man. Now the captains are lookin' at me, not at Ralphie for what he did to that poor girl. I gotta get in front of this. I call a sitdown, get all the captains in a room. I'll lay it all out: Ralphie's insubordination, the disrespect to my place, the heat he brought down. I'll take my lumps for hittin' him, but I'm the boss. I'll fine him, make him pay for the funeral, and put him on notice. This way, I reassert my authority, make the captains see I'm handling business, and avoid a war over a piece of shit like Ralphie. It's about the family, the business. Not him.

Ralphie disrespected me and the family by whacking that broad on my property, but I crossed the line by putting hands on a made guy. Gotta bring the captains together to sort this out proper, keep the peace, and make sure everyone knows where the power lies—my crew loses faith if I let this slide, but we can't tear each other apart over some dancer.

I call a sitdown with the captains and I lay it out straight: what I did to Ralph was outta line, I let my temper go—fine. But what he did was worse for the family. He beat a girl to death in my parking lot, on my property, in front of civilians. That’s not ‘his personal life,’ that’s heat on all of us and it’s disrespect to me and this organization.

So here’s how it goes: I don’t whack him without sanction because I’m not gonna blow up the rules and lose my top earner over a rage moment. But he’s not walking away clean either. I tax him heavy—real heavy—and that money goes to shut people up and to do right by the girl’s people so they don’t start talkin’ to cops or lawyers. I make him cover any exposure: hospital, funeral, whatever keeps it quiet.

Then I put him on a short leash: one more incident like that, one more piece of cowboy shit that brings heat to my door, and I’ll bring it to the Commission if I have to and he’ll get sanctioned proper. Everybody in that room understands the message: made or not, you embarrass the family and endanger the business, the boss responds. And they also understand mine: I’m not gonna make a habit of laying hands on made guys—but I’m also not gonna let captains hide behind ‘rules’ to excuse a liability like Ralph.

I broke a major rule by touching a made guy, and now the other captains are looking at me sideways. Ralphie's a sick fuck for what he did to that girl, but he's also a money machine with the Esplanade. I need to get everyone in a room, smooth over the 'disrespect' to the code, and figure out a way to squeeze Ralphie for his behavior without starting a mutiny. We talk it out, we find a resolution, and I keep my family in line.

Tony needs to gather the captains to address their concerns about him hitting a made man and Ralph's crime. A sitdown can resolve the conflict, get their input, and maintain control of the family without escalating to an irreversible hit or doing nothing which leaves the disrespect unaddressed.

I call a sitdown. Tracee was killed on my club's property — that's an open wound to the Bing and to my business, and Ralphie ain't a civilian, but he went too far. I know I crossed a line by laying hands on a made man, and the captains got cause to be pissed, so we settle it like men: bring everybody in, lay out what happened, accept responsibility for my heat but demand discipline for Ralphie for killing on our turf and bringing heat on the family. I aim to get their backing for whatever corrective action is appropriate — fines, demotion, or a sanctioned punishment — so we contain this without a war. If they stonewall and protect him for the wrong reasons, I make clear I won't let the Bing or my interests be disrespected; but first we talk, negotiate, and try to keep the family intact.

1. **Respect the Commission’s Rules (But Bend ‘Em)**: I can’t just whack Ralphie—no matter how much he deserves it—without the sitdown. The guys are already pissed I laid hands on a made man, and if I go full *Scarface* on Ralphie without the green light, I’m looking at a war with the other families *and* a target on my back. But I ain’t lettin’ this slide either. The sitdown buys me time to make my case—Tracee was under my protection, and Ralphie’s a loose cannon who’s gonna drag us all down if he ain’t reined in.

    2. **Leverage the Captains’ Fear**: The guys are mad I hit Ralphie, but they’re also scared. Scared of me, scared of the heat, scared of the message it sends that even made men ain’t untouchable. I gotta remind ‘em who runs this family. I’ll lay it out: Ralphie’s a liability. He’s drawing heat with his temper, and now he’s got a body on my property? That’s *my* problem now. The sitdown ain’t just about me—it’s about cleaning house before the feds or another family uses this as an excuse to move on us.

    3. **Offer a Compromise (But Keep the Upper Hand)**: I’ll propose a vote to *banish* Ralphie—strip his button, send him to Vegas or fuckin’ Sicily, somewhere far. No blood on my hands, but he’s out. If the captains push back, I’ll dangle the alternative: if we don’t handle this *my* way, I handle it *my* way, and then we got a real problem. Let ‘em sweat. They know I ain’t bluffing.

    4. **Send a Message to the Street**: Even if Ralphie walks outta the sitdown breathing, I make sure the word gets out—*nobody* disrespects the Bing. Not a dancer, not a captain, not even a made man. I’ll have Paulie or Benny “accidentally” leak to the right people that Ralphie’s on thin ice. Let the street do some of the work for me. Fear’s a better enforcer than a bullet sometimes.

    5. **Protect the Family’s Interests**: Ralphie’s a top earner, but he’s a ticking time bomb. If the sitdown goes my way, we replace him with someone smarter, someone who don’t draw heat. If it don’t… well, I got my ways. But I ain’t starting a war over this—not yet. The family comes first, even if it means swallowing my pride for now.

    **Bottom Line**: The sitdown’s a chess move. I play it cool, make the captains think they’re calling the shots, but I’m the one holding the knife. Ralphie’s gonna pay—one way or another.

decision.reasoning:
Feech don’t get it. He’s back two minutes and he’s already big-timing my guys, cutting into routes, ignoring a direct order. If I let that slide, every captain starts thinking they can freelance and we’re done. But whacking him? He’s an old name from my father’s day—blood on my hands for that, I’m buying problems with the old-timers and I don’t need the heat.

So we do it clean. Set him up so he violates parole and goes back inside. No bodies, no war stories, no martyr. It sends the message: you either follow the program or you’re gone. And if anybody asks, it’s simple—Feech couldn’t stay straight, he did it to himself. Meanwhile my authority’s intact, and the business runs the way it’s supposed to.

I can't leave Paulie and Chris out there to freeze or get picked off, but letting that Commie ghost run free risks Slava leveling North Jersey and nuking our car-supply pipeline. I'm pulling Silvio and a couple of reliable earners from Newark—no phones, no goddamn noise—into the Pine Barrens at first light with rifles and a snow-blower just in case. They ghost Valery before he gets word out. Then I take the blame myself, tell Slava I had a rogue crew who overstepped, offer him a bigger cut on the Ecstasy run next month, and hand-deliver the money plus my apologies in Brighton Beach. Show respect, cut your losses, but never let the problem walk back to its handler.

If I send more men into the Pine Barrens, it'll risk more of my own and could keep us tied up in a hunt that may not even end well. But I can't let Valery go either — he's got too much info and is a walking threat. I'll set up a show of force at the outpost, make it look like we're planning something big against Slava. That should lure Valery out. Let him think he has a shot to stop us — then we catch him when he comes sniffing around. Problem solved, partnership stays intact. My way or the highway.

The situation is volatile. Two of my top guys are incompetent and lost in the woods, possibly freezing to death. A trained Russian commando is loose, and if he gets to Slava, our whole operation with the Russians is finished—that's a lot of money. I can't order another hit; my guys are already failing. I need to call an immediate sitdown with Silvio and maybe Bobby to figure out a containment strategy. We need to prepare for Slava. Maybe we can get to him first with a story before Valery does. This needs a strategic discussion, not more impulsive action.

Paulie and Christopher botched it, but letting Valery walk back to Slava means a war we can't afford right now. The Russians are partners, but if Slava finds out we tried to hit his guy, the partnership is dead anyway. We gotta finish the job, send more guys into the Pine Barrens—maybe Bobby or Silvio with a crew—to find Valery and make sure he doesn't talk. We can't have a loose end like that running around, especially not a trained commando. Once Valery is gone, we can deal with Slava diplomatically if we have to, but first we clean up the mess.

Paulie and Chris fucked up royally. They're cold, lost, and Valery's a commando. Sending more soldiers into the Pine Barrens is how I lose more people. But I can't let this sit. Valery gets back to Slava? He'll think we made a move on his guy - that means war, and the Russian partnership is worth millions in construction, waste management, and gas scams.

I need to make this look like Paulie's personal beef, not family-sanctioned. Get Slava on the phone, tell him we got a problem - one of my crews went rogue, tried to shake down Valery for personal cash. I didn't authorize it. I'm fucking mortified. Offer to make it right: pay Valery a compensation package, smooth it over with cash.

But while I'm talking peace, I'm also setting up contingencies. If Valery surfaces and talks, I need to be ready to move on him - quiet, clean, professional. Not Paulie and Chris's amateur hour. I need a real hitter. And if Slava doesn't buy my story? Then it's war anyway, and I need to know where his people sleep, where his money flows, where he's vulnerable.

This is how you manage a crisis: you play both sides. You apologize with one hand, you hold a gun behind your back with the other.

We can’t just “let it go” and hope a commando don’t crawl back to Slava with a story. That’s a war and it kills business. But sending a whole parade into the Pine Barrens is how you turn a botched collection into a state police circus and we lose Paulie and Chrissy on top of it.

While that’s in motion, I keep Slava at arm’s length. No sitdown, no confessions, not until I know how this shook out.
